label: methods
definition: Techniques, methods, procedures, or strategies for research, management, collection, or analysis of scientific information in USGS.

children.label: computational methods
children.definition: Mathematical techniques used to analyze numerical data.

children.label: image analysis
children.definition: Pattern analysis of the shapes and textures of images to identify features and derive information about them.

children.label: structure from motion
children.definition: Mathematical analysis, using photogrammetric principles, of multiple images that depict the same subject from different angles to derive geometrical information and relationships in three-dimensional space that are not inherent in any single image. Often used for deriving land elevation or large scale orthoimagery from a collection of aerial photographs.

children.label: relative abundance analysis
children.definition: Determination of the percentage of individuals of one group in comparison to the total of all individuals in a given area.

children.label: spatial analysis
children.definition: Use of quantitative tools to study social, economic, and geographic data in relation to distributions and patterns in geographic space.

children.label: geospatial analysis
children.definition: Detailed study of information such as measurements, counts, and computations as a function of geographical location.

children.label: contouring
children.definition: Derivation of contours, or other lines of constant value, that visually summarize the spatial variation of some characteristic over an area, for example elevation.

children.label: statistical analysis
children.definition: Branch of mathematics concerned with techniques to collect and interpret data.

children.label: kriging
children.definition: Statistical analysis technique which uses interpolation to best predict unknown data values from data observed at known locations.

children.label: multivariate statistical analysis
children.definition: Statistical study using a number of independent variables or measurements of the same attribute.

children.label: regression analysis
children.definition: Statistical analysis based on the functional relationships of two or more related variables. Predicts the value of one variable when the other two are given.

children.label: time series analysis
children.definition: Statistical analysis using frequency distribution in which time is an independent variable. A sequence of observations collected at regular time intervals is studied.

children.label: topological analysis
children.definition: Branch of geometry concerned with the properties of objects that do not change even when deformed, twisted, stretched or otherwise changed in shape.

children.label: visualization methods
children.definition: The application of two-dimensional or three-dimensional graphical techniques for the analysis and interpretation of complex numerical data.

children.label: acid-base accounting
children.definition: An analytical procedure that provides values to help assess the acid-producing and acid-neutralizing potential of overburden rocks prior to coal mining and other large-scale excavations.

children.label: field methods
children.definition: Research procedures and instrumental means to measure, collect data and samples, and observe in the natural areas where the materials, phenomena, structures, or species being studied occur.

children.label: field experiments
children.definition: Deliberate arrangement of objects and events in the field to observe the behavioral response of natural systems or organisms.

children.label: tracer study
children.definition: Experiments in which stable, easily detected substances or radioisotopes are added to a material to follow the movement of the substance in the environment or to detect any physical or chemical changes with time.

children.label: field inventory and monitoring
children.definition: Repeated observation or sampling at a site, on a scheduled or event basis, for study and analysis.  In general, this category excludes sampling programs in which materials are obtained in the field and brought back to a laboratory for study and analysis.

children.label: borehole logging
children.definition: Method of recording the physical characteristics of the subsurface as a function of depth by observations during drilling of a well or borehole, studying the resulting core, or by lowering instruments into a drilled hole.

children.label: borehole temperature logging
children.definition: Method of recording the measured temperature of the subsurface as a function of depth by lowering instruments into the hole.

children.label: electrical resistivity logging
children.definition: Recordings made to identify the composition of subterranean materials at different depths in a borehole by measuring their ability to resist the flow of an electric current.

children.label: gamma-ray logging
children.definition: Recording of the measurements of natural gamma radiation emitted from the rocks in a borehole to study the subsurface structures.

children.label: CTD measurement
children.definition: Instrumental determination of conductivity, temperature, and pressure as a function of depth to determine the salinity of seawater.

children.label: ecosystem monitoring
children.definition: Recording, evaluating, and actively intervening over time in the interaction of living and nonliving elements in a specific environment.

children.label: long-term ecological monitoring
children.definition: Data collection over a period of years or decades to assess changes in selected biological communities and habitats.

children.label: biomarkers
children.definition: Biochemical, physiological, morphological, or histopathological characteristics of organisms that signify exposure to contaminants.  Also used for biogeochemical measurements of rocks to detect biological origin.

children.label: habitat suitability indices
children.definition: Numerical values calculated for a given area representing the capacity of a habitat to support a given species, as the ratio of observed habitat conditions to optimum conditions.

children.label: electromagnetic surveying
children.definition: Method of determining the shape and constituency of near-surface earth structures by variations of responses of the materials to electrical and magnetic fields. Use for ground-based methods of imaging.

children.label: ground penetrating radar
children.definition: Electromagnetic imaging instrument using radar to investigate shallow subsurface structure.

children.label: magnetotelluric surveying
children.definition: Passive geophysical technique that uses the earth's natural electromagnetic field to investigate the spatial variation of electrical resistivity in the subsurface.

children.label: continuous resistivity profiling
children.definition: Ship-based method of analyzing apparent resistivity of the sub-bottom (for example, spatial variation in pore-water salinity) by measuring the induced electromagnetic response to a current generated by the instruments.

children.label: electrical resistivity imaging
children.definition: Land-based resistivity survey where current is applied to the ground using an array of electrodes and apparent resistivity of the subsurface is measured, giving estimates of the spatial variability of resistivity (for example, variations in pore water salinity).

children.label: handheld field spectroscopy
children.definition: Use of portable equipment to measure spectral reflectance of materials in the field.

children.label: seismic methods
children.definition: Procedures used to record and study earthquakes or earth vibrations including those that are artificially induced.

children.label: seismic networking
children.definition: Deploying, operating, and maintaining groups and arrays of instruments for detecting and describing local movements of the earth.

children.label: seismic reflection methods
children.definition: Geophysical technique to study the subsurface of the earth using sound waves induced by explosives, vibrating devices, or percussive equipment.  The reflections of the sound waves from the boundaries of different rocks are measured.

children.label: sub-bottom profiling
children.definition: Methods of imaging the structure of sediments below the sea floor  or lakebed using ship-borne or towed sensors with a variety of sound sources.

children.label: seismic refraction methods
children.definition: Geophysical technique to study the subsurface of the earth by generating compressional waves by means of hammering or explosive methods. The variations in velocity of the waves traveling through rocks or geological layers are measured.

children.label: sonar methods
children.definition: SOund Navigation And Ranging techniques to detect submerged objects and to determine depths to the bottom of a water body using reflections of sound waves.

children.label: single-beam echo sounder
children.definition: Acoustic technique for determining seafloor or lakebed depth directly below the instrument platform.

children.label: multibeam sonar
children.definition: Acoustic technique for determining depths or creating backscatter imagery in a wide swath of seafloor or lakebed centered below the instrument platform.

children.label: interferometric sonar
children.definition: Acoustic technique for determining depths or creating backscatter imagery in a wide swath of seafloor or lakebed centered below the instrument platform.

children.label: sidescan sonar
children.definition: Acoustic technique for creating oblique backscatter imagery of the seafloor or lakebed.

children.label: stream-gage measurement
children.definition: Use of specialized instruments designed for observing, checking, and recording the water discharge that occurs in a natural channel.

children.label: telemetry
children.definition: Field technique using instruments which measure heat, radiation, speed, or other property and transmit the data to a distant receiver.

children.label: tiltmeter measurement
children.definition: Determination of tiny changes in the slope angle or tilt of the ground in order to monitor deformation caused by moving magma. Instruments detect variations in a liquid level or in the position of a pendulum.

children.label: video monitoring
children.definition: Field study employing the use of filming or repeated photography with stationary optical or digital cameras to observe changes in a feature or organism.

children.label: vocalization methods
children.definition: Series of methods used to (a) record sonograms (sound spectrogram) of animal sounds which are analyzed to identify the presence of species in an area and to determine distinct sound patterns within a species, e.g., mating calls, danger alerts; (b) attract species to an area for inventory or monitoring by playing recorded animal sounds or mimicking them.

children.label: animal and plant census
children.definition: Inventory of macroscopic animals and plants by observation in the field. Used to estimate population and distribution.

children.label: gravimeter measurement
children.definition: Use of a specialized instrument for measuring the earth's gravity at a given location.

children.label: magnetometer measurement
children.definition: Use of specialized instruments designed to measure the earth's magnetic field at a given location.

children.label: optical methods
children.definition: Measurement of light transmission or reflectance in the field to estimate, for example, the density of suspended sediment in water bodies.

children.label: tomography
children.definition: Observation of the internal structure of an object or, as is more typical in USGS research, a cross section of the earth's crust by changing the relative orientation of a signal generator, a sensor, or both.

children.label: acoustic doppler current profiling
children.definition: Field monitoring of water currents using the doppler effect with acoustic instruments.

children.label: statistical surveying
children.definition: Information gathering by asking questions of selected people or organizations.

children.label: field sampling
children.definition: Collecting pieces or specimens or making measurements or observations at determined intervals or areas.  Results may be used as representative of the whole research area or population.

children.label: animal tracking
children.definition: Method of studying wildlife by following physical materials (spoor, footprints, droppings, scent) or remote monitoring of individuals or populations in an area to document the presence and movements of the animals and their interactions within the landscape.

children.label: capturing (animals)
children.definition: Collecting individual animals in the field by various methods in order to obtain information about the species or population and its ecology. Capturing methods are adapted to the habits and habitats of the target species and include both live trapping and kill trapping methods.

children.label: drilling and coring
children.definition: Cutting into the subsurface, for example into underground strata, ice, or a tree trunk, to remove material for examination. Intended for broad use wherever coring is done. The combination of this term with other terms will convey the context of the activity.

children.label: box coring
children.definition: Use of a rectangular box pushed into soft sediment with a spade to facilitate lifting the sampled material, to isolate and extract relatively undisturbed underwater sediment.

children.label: gravity coring
children.definition: Use of a simple tube pushed into underwater sediments by an overhanging weight, to extract relatively undisturbed material for study.

children.label: piston coring
children.definition: Use of a piston mechanism and a weight with a triggering mechanism to drive a coring tube deep into underwater sediments for extraction and study.

children.label: augering
children.definition: Use of a device with rotating blades and possibly helical flanges to dig holes in unconsolidated material for subsurface sampling.

children.label: push coring
children.definition: Use of a small, hand-held tube pressed into unconsolidated material for sampling.

children.label: rotary drilling
children.definition: Use of machinery to drive a rotating bit through earth materials in order to sample below the surface.

children.label: vibracoring
children.definition: Application of vibration to a coring device in order to achieve greater penetration for sampling unconsolidated material.

children.label: plant and animal tagging
children.definition: Methods of attaching a tag or marker to an organism as long-term identification for study purposes.

children.label: plot sampling
children.definition: Outlining small areas of land within a larger area to use as samples to study biological populations or ecosystems.

children.label: sexing (plants & animals)
children.definition: Determination of the sex of an individual organism for study purposes, such as wildlife surveys.

children.label: specimen collecting
children.definition: Taking of samples from the environment for study.

children.label: transect sampling
children.definition: Systematic method of collecting field data by recording observations or collecting specimens along a vector or measured course across the environment.

children.label: trenching
children.definition: Field method used by earth scientists to study the underground structure of an area. A long narrow ditch is dug to locate geologic features, such as a fault.

children.label: water sampling
children.definition: Methods of collecting a representative part of a body of water for testing in controlled conditions.

children.label: dredge sampling
children.definition: Collection of material from the bottom of a body of water by dragging an open container along the floor of the water body and returning the collected material to the investigators.

children.label: grab sampling
children.definition: Use of a mechanical device to seize a volume of unconsolidated surficial material for study.  This term applies when the device used is specifically crafted for grab sampling.

children.label: geolocation measurement
children.definition: Methods for establishing a geographic location on the surface of the earth.

children.label: altimetry measurement
children.definition: The measurement of altitude, or height above mean sea level, using instruments such as aneroid barometers and radar altimeters.

children.label: bathymetry measurement
children.definition: Means of determining the depth to the floor of a body of water, especially the ocean.

children.label: GPS measurement
children.definition: Determination of distance and location using instruments receiving signals from the Global Positioning System, a system of satellites for identifying earth locations.

children.label: land surveying
children.definition: Determining property boundaries, land area, elevations, and locations of features on the surface of the land by calculations based on the instrumental measurements of angles and distances or by use of global positional satellites.

children.label: LORAN-C navigation
children.definition: Hyperbolic radio navigation system used for near-shore waters.

children.label: real-time monitoring and reporting
children.definition: Gathering information through periodic or continuous measurement in the field to provide a view of current conditions. In some instances, observations may not be subject to rigorous review before release; this will be noted in the documentation accompanying the data.

children.label: laboratory methods
children.definition: Techniques to analyze and test samples in a place equipped and designed for the work.

children.label: chemical analysis
children.definition: Chemical techniques used to identify the composition of substances.

children.label: atomic absorption analysis
children.definition: Technique used to identify chemicals based on the measurement of the spectra produced by atoms and molecules with absorption of electromagnetic radiation.

children.label: chromatography
children.definition: Analytical techniques used to separate or partition the components of a gaseous or liquid mixture by differences in absorption rates during flow around or over surface absorbents such as columns of silica, filter papers, or gels.

children.label: gas chromatography
children.definition: Chromatographic technique used to separate or partition the components of a mixture.  Solid and liquid samples are vaporized and passed through a column containing a liquid that differentially absorbs the  molecules.

children.label: liquid chromatography
children.definition: Chromatographic technique to separate or partition the components of a mixture in which samples are liquid and passed through a column.

children.label: DNA sequencing
children.definition: Biochemical procedure to determine the order of nucleotides in genes.

children.label: electrophoresis
children.definition: Analytical technique to separate and identify components in a mixture using the differential migration of molecules based on their net charge through a paper or gel medium.

children.label: flow cytometry
children.definition: Laboratory technique to determine the amount of DNA in cells tagged by fluorescent dye by measuring the intensity of fluorescence under a laser beam.

children.label: mass spectroscopy
children.definition: Instrumental technique to separate and identify molecules.  Gaseous ions are formed, with or without fragmentation.  Their mass/charge ratios and relative electrical abundance are then measured or the spectra are recorded.

children.label: neutron activation analysis
children.definition: Sensitive laboratory technique for both qualitative and quantitative analysis of elements in samples.  Target nuclei are bombarded with neutron beams to start nuclear reactions which emit characteristic gamma ray radiations.

children.label: particle-beam spectroscopy
children.definition: Analytical technique using a concentrated beam of charged subatomic particles.

children.label: polymerase chain reaction
children.definition: Biochemical technique that uses enzymes to replicate new nucleotides of DNA from DNA triphosphates using DNA as a template.

children.label: x-ray diffraction
children.definition: Study of crystals which uses short wave electromagnetic radiations (x-rays). The xrays, scattered by the crystal atoms, show a characteristic interference pattern that is dependent upon the structure of the crystal.

children.label: atomic emission spectroscopy
children.definition: Chemical detection of element concentration by examining the intensity and wavelength of light emitted from the sample when gaseous sample is ionized and maintained in a plasma state.

children.label: x-ray fluorescence
children.definition: Estimation of chemical element concentration by measuring the energy level of secondary X-rays generated when the sample is bombarded with high-energy X-rays or gamma rays.

children.label: core analysis
children.definition: Study of the composition and layers of cylindrical samples of rocks, trees, ice, and other materials extracted by drilling into a mass. Intended for broad use for the analysis of all types of core samples. The combination of this term with other terms will convey the context of the activity.

children.label: culturing (specimens)
children.definition: Growing microorganisms, tissue cells, or other living matter in a specially prepared nutrient medium for diagnostic or scientific use.

children.label: faunal and floral census (microscopic)
children.definition: Records of counts of the different microscopic species in a core, soil, sediment, rock or water sample to determine geologic age or other characteristic of the sample.  Use for microscopic examinations.

children.label: grain-size analysis
children.definition: Method of studying soils, sediments, sands, or rock by determining the size, distribution, and proportion of selected particles.

children.label: sieve-size analysis
children.definition: Analytic technique determining the distribution of the different sizes of particles in soil, sediment, or rock samples by measuring the percentage that will pass through mesh holes of known size.

children.label: isotopic analysis
children.definition: Experimental determination of the proportion of a given isotope (or isotopes) in a sample.

children.label: light stable isotope analysis
children.definition: Analytical technique using mass spectrometry to measure the different isotopic forms of low mass (light) elements such as oxygen, hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen and sulfur that occur in samples.

children.label: beryllium isotope analysis
children.definition: Method of age determination based on measurement of the activity of beryllium-10, used in dating deep-sea sediments, and in determining sedimentation rates.

children.label: carbon isotope analysis
children.definition: Experimental determination of the proportion of a given stable carbon isotope (C12 or C13) in a sample.

children.label: oxygen isotope analysis
children.definition: Experimental determination of the proportion of a given stable oxygen isotope in a sample.

children.label: tritium analysis
children.definition: Mass spectrometric measurement of the decay of the radioactive isotope of hydrogen in water samples as a means of dating and investigating changes in water.

children.label: radiometric dating
children.definition: Methods for age determination of rocks and fossils by measuring the proportions of naturally occurring radioactive isotopes to their decay products.

children.label: carbon-14 analysis
children.definition: Method to determine the age of organic geologic and archaeological specimens, aged approximately 3,000 to 50,000 years, by determining the decay of the radioactive isotope carbon-14.

children.label: rubidium-strontium analysis
children.definition: Technique for dating ancient rocks based on measuring the ratio of the isotopes strontium-87 to ribidium-87 in samples. Uses the known half-life of radioactive isotopes of rubidium-87 that decay to isotopes of strontium-87 to determine rock ages.

children.label: uranium-lead analysis
children.definition: Radiometric dating technique to determine the age of earth materials from the ratio of the radioactive isotopes of uranium-235 or uranium-238 to the lead isotope decay products in the sample. The ratio is compared to the known half-life of the uranium isotopes.

children.label: uranium-thorium analysis
children.definition: Radiometric dating technique used to determine the age of earth materials based on determining the ratio of uranium-238 to the decay product thorium-230. The ratio is compared to the known half-life of the uranium isotope.

children.label: potassium-argon analysis
children.definition: Radiometric age determination by comparison of the concentrations of radioactive potassium and argon daughter products.

children.label: meristics
children.definition: Branch of zoology concerned with classifying animals by counting and measuring body parts.

children.label: microscopy
children.definition: Laboratory methods using instruments that employ optical lenses or radiation to study objects too small to be seen by the naked eye.

children.label: electron microscopy
children.definition: Study of small particles of matter with a microscope that produces a magnified image by using a beam of electrons focused by magnetic lenses.

children.label: scanning electron microscopy
children.definition: Microscope in which a finely focused beam of electrons is scanned across a specimen. The electronic intensity variations observed are used to construct an image of the specimen.

children.label: optical microscopy
children.definition: Scientific techniques using a microscope with one or more lenses illuminated with visible light to view small objects.

children.label: microtomy
children.definition: Laboratory methods using special instruments, or microtomes, to cut very thin slices of specimens for microscopic studies.

children.label: paleomagnetic analysis
children.definition: Determination of the intensity and direction of residual magnetism in rocks to study changes in the earth's magnetic field during past geologic time.

children.label: Curie temperature analysis
children.definition: Analysis of rock specimens using the Curie temperature point above which ferromagnetic materials lose permanent magnetism.

children.label: laboratory-induced magnetization analysis
children.definition: Laboratory method to study rocks using magnetometers to measure remanent magnetic fields induced in the samples.

children.label: magnetic hysteresis analysis
children.definition: Nondestructive evaluation of ferromagnetic materials.  The evaluation is based on measurement of the variation of intensity of magnetization within an applied magnetic field due to changes in the magnetic domain structure of the materials under study.

children.label: magnetic susceptibility analysis
children.definition: Nondestructive evaluation and location of magnetic materials in rock based on measuring the intensity of attraction of the materials to an induced magnetic field. Applications include geological and soil surveys, paleomagnetic studies, sedimentology, archaeological prospecting and core logging.

children.label: natural remanent magnetization analysis
children.definition: Method which measures the intensity and direction of residual magnetism in rocks to determine their age and history.

children.label: petrography
children.definition: Use of optical microscopy for the description and classification of rocks.

children.label: plant and animal testing
children.definition: Use of live or dead organisms for scientific study.

children.label: therapeutic methods
children.definition: Methods of  restoring health with remedial agents or treatments.

children.label: tree ring analysis
children.definition: Study of the variations in width and number of tree rings to date historical events and to study periods of climatic and hydrologic changes.

children.label: camera calibration
children.definition: Optical calibration of cameras that are typically used in airborne remote sensing.

children.label: age estimation methods
children.definition: Methods used to determine the age of earth materials, typically by laboratory analysis of properties of those materials.

children.label: fission-track dating
children.definition: Laboratory technique for determining the age of rocks and other geological materials by counts of spontaneous and induced fission tracks left by the radioactive isotope uranium-238.

children.label: luminescence dating
children.definition: Dating methods that involve the analysis of the optical properties of minerals exposed to environmental radiation.  Typically used to determine the age of subaerial exposure of surficial sediments.

children.label: tephrochronology
children.definition: Age determination of rocks and deposits by correlation of volcanic ash layers (tephra) that bound the deposits below and above.

children.label: sclerochronology
children.definition: Description of the history of individual organisms by studying the variations in thickness of accretionary layers in their skeletons.

children.label: subsampling
children.definition: Preparation of study materials by dividing or slicing cores, samples, or other collected materials.

children.label: laboratory experiments
children.definition: Procedures carried out in a laboratory under controlled conditions to test specific scientific hypotheses.

children.label: management methods
children.definition: Techniques of judiciously controlling or directing resources for a predetermined goal.

children.label: decision support methods
children.definition: Mathematical, analytical, and social procedures used to aid groups and individuals in the process of making decisions.  Includes protocols for discussion and mechanisms for facilitating communication among disparate groups as well as mechanical and technological aids to analysis and understanding.

children.label: ecosystem services valuation
children.definition: Assessment of the value of ecosystem functions in supporting, sustaining, or enriching life.

children.label: environmental assessment
children.definition: The evaluation of the status of a specific ecosystem or geographic area and how a proposed change in management or a proposed project will affect that status.

children.label: TMDL
children.definition: A calculation of the maximum amount of a pollutant that a waterbody can receive and still meet water-quality standards.

children.label: hazard preparedness
children.definition: Awareness of the consequences of hazards and actions to be taken before, during, or after hazards occur or are encountered.

children.label: earthquake preparedness
children.definition: Awareness of the consequences of earthquake events and actions to be taken before, during, or after events.

children.label: aviation safety
children.definition: Effects on air transportation of natural hazards such as volcanic activity (ash plumes and volcanic clouds).

children.label: information technology methods
children.definition: Information-related concerns on which people focus their work in support of scientific investigations and research.

children.label: data management
children.definition: Activities focused on the creation, documentation, and preservation of scientific data with the intent that the data continue to be usable in the future.

children.label: improvement of scientific data usability
children.definition: Retrospective modification of the structure, format, packaging, or documentation of an existing scientific data resource to improve the likelihood of effective use of the data by individuals or organizations who did not create the data.

children.label: data preservation
children.definition: Design, development, and implementation of methods for ensuring that scientific information remain accessible and usable despite changes in technology and strategic directions in the originating organzation.

children.label: data rescue
children.definition: Reduction of the risk that scientific information will be lost or become unusable in the future.  Includes copying data from unstable to stable media, conversion of data files from unusable to usable formats, and creation of metadata allowing further changes to the data and other characteristics to be documented.

children.label: metadata management
children.definition: Curation and maintenance of the documentation for scientific information resources.  Includes editing the metadata to improve consistency, completeness, and correctness, and modification of the structure of the documentation to improve its effectiveness in actual use.

children.label: digitization
children.definition: Compilation in digital form of data previously presented in analog forms such as contours on paper maps, plots, or other graphical materials, so that the digital data produced approximates the scientific measurements used to create the original printed materials.

children.label: information system administration
children.definition: Design, deployment, and maintenance of computing systems that support creation, maintenance, and use of scientific information.

children.label: database administration
children.definition: Design and implementation of strategies for arranging information within database management systems (including but not restricted to relational database management systems) so that the integrity and consistency of the information supports its intended uses.

children.label: network administration
children.definition: Methods for ensuring that computers communicate effectively with one another and follow established standards and guidelines for ensuring integrity in exchanging information and efficiency in operation.

children.label: information system security
children.definition: Methods for ensuring that information systems are used for their intended purpose by those entitled to use them and that the information they contain retains its integrity and, where appropriate, confidentiality.

children.label: data communication
children.definition: Design, development, and deployment of methods to convey scientific information to potential users.

children.label: social network development
children.definition: Design and use of software and interfaces that facilitate interchange of information among people or organizations that produce scientific data and the potential users of those data.  Primarily refers to interactive web interfaces and services that enable discussion, collaboration, and comment on the data.

children.label: web interface development
children.definition: Design of user interfaces for scientific information that are accessed using web browser software.

children.label: data packaging
children.definition: Design of the structure, format, and arrangement of scientific data in digital files in order to facilitate their transfer and effective use by people and organizations other than the originators.

children.label: web service development
children.definition: Design and deployment of data services accessed using the hypertext transfer protocol.

children.label: markup and query language development
children.definition: Design of the structure and format of digital queries and responses concerning scientific data resources.  Refers to exchanges in which the structure and content of the queries is interpreted by software both when generated and when received.

children.label: data integration
children.definition: Strategies which, when implemented, enable disparate data to be combined in a single analysis.  Includes combination of similar data from small components into larger, coherent assemblages as well as recognizing and exploiting relationships linking or connecting data that are maintained separately.  May include efforts to make scientific information more easily found and obtained.

children.label: information architecture
children.definition: Design of conceptual, logical, and physical information system components (both data and software) to support effective maintenance, integration, or use of the data.

children.label: knowledge organization system development
children.definition: Design and development of information systems that represent and relate concepts needed to identify, specify, organize, categorize, or characterize scientific information effectively.  Includes development of controlled vocabularies as well as hierarchical and networked concept schemes such as thesauri and ontologies.

children.label: software development
children.definition: Design and development of procedures and instructions by which  information is modified or presented.

children.label: natural resource management
children.definition: Using a combination of techniques to control or direct the use of resources and limit population size to reach a predetermined goal, such as sustainability.

children.label: biological population management
children.definition: Judicious means of controlling or directing numbers and life conditions of organisms living in a specific locality to achieve a selected goal.

children.label: fishery management
children.definition: Controlling or directing numbers and life conditions of fish living in a specific locality to achieve a selected goal.

children.label: reintroduction (organisms)
children.definition: Return of a species to an area through the intervention of man.

children.label: wildlife population management
children.definition: Monitoring and control of wildlife as a sustainable natural asset.

children.label: game management
children.definition: Scientific monitoring and control of hunted wildlife.

children.label: pest control
children.definition: Intentional reduction in the abundance of specific harmful organisms in a given area.

children.label: controlled flooding
children.definition: The deliberate inundation of land or wetland, or an increase in river flow below dams for restoration or research purposes. Do not confuse with flood control.

children.label: ecosystem management
children.definition: Means of controlling or directing human practices, species populations, and physical environment within an ecosystem to achieve a selected state of sustainability.

children.label: natural resource assessment
children.definition: Estimation of the actual or potential value of natural materials and processes.

children.label: carbon dioxide storage assessment
children.definition: Estimates of the storage capacity of carbon dioxide in geologic units at depths of 3,000 to 13,000 feet that are capable of maintaining carbon dioxide in a supercritical state.

children.label: remediation
children.definition: Methods for decontaminating, reclaiming, and restoring natural resources or reducing the effects of hazards.

children.label: bioremediation
children.definition: Use of biological methods, usually involving microorganisms, to break down or neutralize contaminants in soil, water, and wastes.

children.label: water resource management
children.definition: Methods of controlling or directing resources and activities related to water for a predetermined goal.

children.label: watershed management
children.definition: Controlling and directing the resources and activities associated with the land and streams of a drainage basin to maintain the supply and quality of water and prevent floods, erosions, and other destructive conditions.

children.label: fire control
children.definition: Human intervention to restrict or prevent fires in forests and grasslands.

children.label: controlled fires
children.definition: Prescribed burns used to burn trees, brush, and undergrowth that would fuel a large wildfire.  Do not confuse this term with 'fire control'.  It is one of the tools used in fire control.

children.label: beach nourishment
children.definition: Transfer of sand from offshore areas to resupply beach areas that have been eroded.

children.label: risk assessment
children.definition: The evaluation of the likelihood of adverse effects due to a given factor such as energy development or recurring hazardous events such as earthquakes.

children.label: earthquake probabilities
children.definition: That aspect of seismology that deals with the physical conditions or indications that precede an earthquake, in order to predict its probability, size, time, and location.

children.label: landslide susceptibility assessment
children.definition: Estimation of the probability of occurrence and likely severity of landslides in a given area.

children.label: volcanic eruption prediction
children.definition: Estimation of future volcanic activity using geological and geophysical observations.

children.label: mitigation of coastal hazards
children.definition: Actions taken to reduce risk of physical disruption in coastal environments.

children.label: hard shoreline stabilization
children.definition: Use of engineered structures to armor or otherwise protect the shoreline against erosional agents such as waves and currents.  Includes breakwaters, bulkheads, seawalls, groins, jetties, and revetments.

children.label: soft shoreline stabilization
children.definition: Mitigating coastal erosion by managing the sediment budget (for example, beach nourishment or sand bypassing) or restoring dunes and wetlands (for example, by planting erosion-resistant vegetation).

children.label: coastal infrastructure relocation
children.definition: Landward relocation of infrastructure to reduce the risk from coastal hazards.

children.label: adaptive management
children.definition: A decision-making process aiming to reduce uncertainty through system monitoring and feedback, used for environmental or resource management.

children.label: photography
children.definition: Process of using digital or film cameras to collect images of objects.

children.label: underwater photography
children.definition: Photographs taken below the water surface, usually in marine, lacustrine, and estuarine environments.  Subjects are typically benthic organisms and sedimentary structures on the bottom.

children.label: remote sensing
children.definition: Acquiring information about a natural feature or phenomenon, such as the Earth's surface, without actually being in contact with it. USGS remote sensing is usually carried out with airborne or spaceborne sensors or cameras.

children.label: aerial photography
children.definition: The process of taking pictures with a camera from an aircraft. Use for both the process of photography from the air and the images produced by the process.

children.label: aeromagnetic surveying
children.definition: Mapping of the earth's magnetic field with the use of airborne electronic magnetometers.

children.label: aeroradiometric surveying
children.definition: Mapping of gamma radiation from the earth's surface with airborne scintillation meters or gamma-ray spectrometers.

children.label: hyperspectral imaging
children.definition: Multispectral imaging technique that records many bands of imagery at very narrow bandwidths.

children.label: IFSAR
children.definition: Interferometric comparison of radar reflectance imagery of the same area at different times to determine changes in the land surface, typically from a space-borne sensor.

children.label: infrared imaging
children.definition: Method of remote sensing in which optical sensors produce visible representations of infrared rays or radiated heat from the observed objects and the temperature variations are represented by different colors in the image.

children.label: AVHRR
children.definition: Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer or broad-band, four or five channel scanner, sensing in the visible, near-infrared, and thermal infrared portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. This information is used to estimate characteristics of the land and sea surface such as temperature and overall health of vegetation.

children.label: lidar
children.definition: Light detection and ranging, an airborne, spaceborne or ground-based laser-ranging technique commonly used for acquiring high-resolution topographic data.

children.label: microwave imaging
children.definition: Remote sensing method using short high frequency electromagnetic waves reflected or radiated from the ground.

children.label: SMMR
children.definition: Scanning Multichannel Microwave Radiometer (SMMR), a technique which uses a multichannel microwave radiometer mounted on an airplane or satellite to measure polarized microwave radiances from the atmosphere, seas or land. Temperatures, wind speeds, sea ice coverage, and terrain parameters can be obtained.

children.label: SSM/I
children.definition: Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I), technique using passive microwave radiometers aboard satellites to measure the microwave reflectivity of the earth, oceans, and the atmosphere.

children.label: multispectral imaging
children.definition: A method of remote sensing that obtains optical representations in two or more ranges of frequencies or wave lengths.

children.label: panchromatic imaging
children.definition: Photographic technique which uses emulsions, films, or plates sensitive to all colors in light to produce black-and-white photographs. Often used in aerial and satellite photography.

children.label: radar imaging
children.definition: A remote sensing technique which uses the reflection of pulsed high frequency radio waves to determine the speed, direction, and distance of faraway objects.

children.label: SLAR
children.definition: Side-looking Airborne Radar, an airborne radar imaging technique, uses an antenna mounted on an airplane or satellite to project radiation at right angles to the flight path and collect high resolution images.

children.label: doppler radar imaging
children.definition: Exploitation of the doppler effect in radar imaging to determine speed of airborne objects such as birds, butterflies, and clouds.

children.label: thermal imaging
children.definition: Remote sensing techniques using instruments to measure emitted thermal radiation to form images of the earth's surface.

children.label: visible light imaging
children.definition: Remote sensing methods using electromagnetic radiation which is visible to the human eye to react with the coating on a photographic plate or film.

children.label: videography
children.definition: The process of recording and editing analog or digital video.

children.label: scientific interpretation
children.definition: Application of scientific judgment as to the meaning of observations or models. Use for interpretations that are provided in formats similar to data, such as geospatial data.

children.label: environmental proxies
children.definition: Biological, chemical, or physical features whose presence, characteristics, or behavior reflect environmental parameters of interest that cannot be readily or efficiently observed or measured directly.

children.label: modeling
children.definition: Human-constructed representation of processes, phenomena, or objects so that the behaviors, characteristics and relationships among things that are being studied can be understood without exhaustive data collection and analysis.

children.label: mathematical modeling
children.definition: Operational representation of a system in which the characteristics and behaviors of the component processes, phenomena, or objects, understood using mathematical relationships, are represented by numerical values (measured or hypothetical), so that calculations carried out using them return numerical estimates of system parameters that were not measured directly.

children.label: mathematical simulation
children.definition: A computer algorithm or model, which was created to represent a simplified version of a real world situation.

children.label: inverse modeling
children.definition: An iterative approach to estimate the form and characteristics of a physical system explained by observations or measurements. Frequently used to determine a subsurface geological structure from measurements of physical properties obtained at or near the earth's surface.

children.label: conceptual modeling
children.definition: Representation of a system indicating the relationships among concepts, objects, or processes involved in the system, used to help people understand or simulate the system it represents. Often realized using diagrams or generalized schemas.

children.label: state and transition modeling
children.definition: Modeling of systems such as ecosystems to predict the consequences of natural events and management actions by describing how specified events and actions may change the components and relationships in the system.

children.label: physical modeling
children.definition: Physical arrangement of materials or objects, to enact processes involving them. The system is understood by observing and reporting the resulting arrangement, behavior, and composition of those materials or objects.

label: product types
definition: General representation of the information in a resource, such as a map or data set.

children.label: catalogs and indexes
children.definition: Detailed enumeration of related items listed in a given order, or alphabetical lists of topics used for information retrieval.

children.label: bibliographies
children.definition: List of publications on a given topic, by an author or group, or published in a specific time period. Limited here to lists primarily of paper documents.

children.label: directories
children.definition: Searchable lists of people, typically USGS staff.

children.label: gazetteers
children.definition: Indexed collections of geographic names.

children.label: datasets
children.definition: Digital information in a format suitable for direct input to software that can analyze its meaning in the scientific, engineering, or business context for which the data were collected.

children.label: geospatial datasets
children.definition: Collections of related digital information that are geographically referenced.

children.label: digital elevation models
children.definition: Gridded elevation, geographically referenced to the surface of the earth, as digital data

children.label: navigational data
children.definition: Geospatial data indicating the locations of instruments, vessels, aircraft, or other vehicles used to collect scientific observations.  These data include horizontal coordinates in sequence, and may include time or vertical position.

children.label: study areas
children.definition: Geospatial data describing the areas from which samples were taken or observations were made, typically polygonal.  May be approximate, as in bounding coordinates, or precise.

children.label: assessment units
children.definition: Geographic areas for which a valuable resource is estimated.  Frequently defined in two or more dimensions, for example specifying underground formations in a given geographic area.  Functions or services may be estimated in addition to material resources.

children.label: hydrographic datasets
children.definition: Datasets for graphs showing variation of water elevation, velocity, streamflow, or other property of water with respect to time.

children.label: time series datasets
children.definition: Digital information describing observations taken at specified time intervals.  The time interval may be regular or variable; the type of observed phenomena and the location are typically constant.

children.label: profiles
children.definition: Observations or calculations given for a series of depths, at or near the same horizontal position.

children.label: reports
children.definition: Written items, especially those that are official, factual, or informative, often including graphics as well as text.

children.label: checklists
children.definition: Inventories or lists of related items for checking off or reference.

children.label: guidebooks
children.definition: Books intended to direct and instruct travelers in a given area and often geared to special interests, such as observing local birds, understanding geological features, or locating endemic plants.

children.label: manuals
children.definition: Documents giving instructions on using specified equipment or accomplishing specified tasks.

children.label: standards
children.definition: An object or instrument of known properties used as a model, for comparison, or a set of rules used to assure quality.

children.label: conference proceedings
children.definition: Collections of abstracts or papers given during a specific meeting, conference, or workshop.

children.label: strategic plans
children.definition: Documents describing overall strategy, not presenting substantive scientific findings.

children.label: image collections
children.definition: Visible representations of objects or earth properties produced by cameras, spectral instruments, or as graphical representations of measurements.

children.label: image mosaics
children.definition: Composite images formed by overlapping existing images, typically arranged to achieve greater spatial coverage.

children.label: maps and atlases
children.definition: Representation, usually on a flat surface, of a part or whole of the Earth or other parts of the universe.  Collections of maps linked digitally or bound together in a book are called atlases.

children.label: geologic maps
children.definition: Maps depicting geological characteristics of the earth's surface, including lithology, geologic structure, age, and the results of crustal processes. Used where the product includes a depiction of the map as a whole, not for data sets that could be used to create a map.

children.label: topographic maps
children.definition: Maps depicting the elevation and relief of the land surface or depth of a water body (bathymetry) in an area, usually shown using contour lines.  Typically these maps include manmade features and administrative boundaries as well as vegetation and hydrographic features.

children.label: posters
children.definition: Large single sheets of paper or board imprinted with informative text and graphics. Intended for hanging or flat display.

children.label: scientific software
children.definition: Routines, programs, and procedures devised in order to direct computers to perform specific tasks.

children.label: official communications
children.definition: Corporate releases of information by USGS not generally intended to document the details of scientific data or techniques for a scientific audience.

children.label: news releases
children.definition: Short information memoranda issued by organizations to highlight new activities, appointments, or discoveries for the news media.

children.label: policies and regulations
children.definition: Rules, orders, and procedures issued by organizations or governments for administrative, controlling, and managing purposes.

children.label: videos
children.definition: Animation or other motion pictures, including videotape and DVD products.

children.label: materials standards
children.definition: Physical materials such as chemicals, rocks, water, or biological materials that are used for reference when carrying out laboratory analysis.

children.label: presentation materials
children.definition: Diagrams, photos, and text gathered together as part of a presentation given in a meeting or class.

children.label: sound recordings
children.definition: Information presented in a format for listening by the user.

children.label: animations
children.definition: Graphical representation of scientific data presented as a timed sequence of visual images, normally without sound.

children.label: terminologies and classifications
children.definition: Collections of terms often including definitions or scope notes, with some stated relationships among terms

children.label: geologic time scales
children.definition: Named divisions of geologic time used to specify relationships among geologic units and structural features

children.label: field activity logs
children.definition: Operational records for observation, inventory, sampling, or monitoring activities.

label: sciences
definition: Major educational fields, fields of study, and professional groupings within USGS.

children.label: earth sciences
children.definition: Broad term for all science related to the study of the earth.

children.label: atmospheric sciences
children.definition: Studies relating to composition, structure, physics, chemistry, and dynamics of the atmosphere.

children.label: climatology
children.definition: Scientific study of the characteristic weather conditions of geographic areas.

children.label: meteorology
children.definition: Branch of science dealing with the short-term variations of atmospheric conditions including wind, precipitation, temperature, humidity, cloud cover, and air pressure.

children.label: geochemistry
children.definition: Study of the distribution of chemical elements and natural compounds on the earth and in the atmosphere and the chemical processes that affect the earth.

children.label: soil chemistry
children.definition: Branch of chemistry concerned with the elements and compounds that make up soils. Includes chemical processes involving soils.

children.label: water chemistry
children.definition: Branch of chemistry that deals with the elements and compounds in water.

children.label: marine chemistry
children.definition: Branch of chemistry that deals with the properties, composition, structure, and interaction of substances in the seas and oceans.

children.label: geography
children.definition: Study of the earth's landforms, topography, and climate, the distribution of flora and fauna, and the distribution, culture, and activities of human populations.

children.label: cartography
children.definition: The science and art of making maps.

children.label: paleogeography
children.definition: Study of the history of earth surface characteristics; geomorphology in the past.

children.label: geology
children.definition: Study of the planet earth, its composition, structure, physical and chemical processes, and history since its origin.

children.label: economic geology
children.definition: Scientific study of the formation, location, and use of marketable geologic materials including fuels, metals, minerals, and water.

children.label: geochronology
children.definition: Study of the age of the earth by dating geological formations, rocks, and fossils.

children.label: geomorphology
children.definition: Branch of geology dealing with surface land features and the processes that create and change them.

children.label: hydrogeology
children.definition: Study of subsurface waters and geologic aspects of surface waters.

children.label: marine geology
children.definition: Branch of geology concerned with the composition, geologic history, and earth processes of the ocean floor and the continental margin.

children.label: mineralogy
children.definition: Branch of earth sciences concerned with the study of naturally occurring inorganic elements or compounds.

children.label: petrology
children.definition: Branch of earth sciences concerned with the origin, structure, alteration, and composition of rocks.

children.label: sedimentology
children.definition: Branch of earth sciences concerned with the study of the origin, composition, transport, and changes of materials deposited by water, wind, or ice.

children.label: stratigraphy
children.definition: Branch of geology concerned with the study of the formation, composition, ordering in time, and arrangement in space of stratified rocks.

children.label: biostratigraphy
children.definition: Branch of geology concerned with the separation and differentiation of rock units based on the fossils they contain.

children.label: lithostratigraphy
children.definition: Branch of stratigraphy dealing with the study of units of rock. Each unit is composed of a body of rock which is dominated by a certain lithology or similar color, mineralogic composition, and grain size.

children.label: structural geology
children.definition: Branch of geology concerned with the distribution, position, shape, and internal structure of rocks.

children.label: volcanology
children.definition: The branch of geology that deals with volcanism and the processes involved in magma flow and eruption through a vent in the earth's surface.

children.label: geophysics
children.definition: Branch of geology studying the physical characteristics and phenomena of the earth and its atmosphere.

children.label: geodesy
children.definition: Branch of science dealing with measuring the earth or large areas of the earth for making maps, determining the size and shape of the earth, and correlating gravitational, geological, and magnetic surveys of the earth.

children.label: marine geophysics
children.definition: Branch of earth sciences concerned with the physical processes of the oceans and continental margins.  We include here studies of large bodies of brackish and fresh water, such as lakes and rivers.

children.label: seismology
children.definition: Branch of earth sciences concerned with the study of earthquakes and man-induced seismic waves.

children.label: paleoseismology
children.definition: Branch of seismology concerned with ancient earthquakes.  Clues which indicate seismic activities in the geologic past are used  to date and determine the effects of those earthquakes.

children.label: tectonophysics
children.definition: Branch of geophysics concerned with the structural forces affecting the deformation, uplift, and movement of the earth's crust.

children.label: glaciology
children.definition: Science dealing with the features, origins, processes, and properties of snow, ice, glaciers, and ice sheets.

children.label: hydrology
children.definition: Branch of earth science that deals with water as it occurs in the atmosphere, on the surface of the ground, and underground.

children.label: hydrodynamics
children.definition: Principles of fluid dynamics applied to water bodies.

children.label: limnology
children.definition: Scientific study of the physical and biological characteristics of inland bodies of water such as lakes and ponds.

children.label: ocean sciences
children.definition: Sciences involved in the study of geological, biological, chemical, and physical characteristics and processes of the oceans.

children.label: paleoceanography
children.definition: Study of the oceans in the geologic past, including their physical, chemical, biologic, and geologic history.

children.label: paleontology
children.definition: Study of life in past geologic time based on fossil plants and animals.

children.label: invertebrate paleontology
children.definition: Branch of paleontology which deals with fossil animals without backbones.

children.label: micropaleontology
children.definition: Branch of paleontology dealing with fossils too small to be seen without a microscope.

children.label: paleobotany
children.definition: Branch of paleontology concerned with the study of fossil plants and plant life in the geologic past.

children.label: vertebrate paleontology
children.definition: Branch of paleontology dealing with fossil animals that have spinal columns.

children.label: soil sciences
children.definition: Earth sciences dealing with the origin, classification, physical, chemical, and biological properties of soils.

children.label: engineering sciences
children.definition: Sciences involved in the application of scientific and mathematical principles to construction, machinery, mechanical design, mining and manufacturing processes and other practical activities.

children.label: engineering geology
children.definition: Branch of geology involved in the application of soil and rock mechanics, natural hazards, and other geological studies to the practice of engineering and construction.

children.label: hydraulic engineering
children.definition: Branch of engineering which applies the physical properties of fluids, such as flow and pressure, to the design and use of machinery, pumps, pipelines, etc.

children.label: information sciences
children.definition: Sciences dealing with the compilation, processing, classification, display, transmission, storage, and retrieval of recorded knowledge.

children.label: biological informatics
children.definition: Development and use of computer, statistical, and other tools in the collection, organization, dissemination, and use of information to solve problems in the life sciences.

children.label: computer science
children.definition: Study of computers, including their design (architecture),  uses (computations, data processing), and systems control.

children.label: life sciences
children.definition: Branches of science that study living and fossil organisms.

children.label: anatomy and physiology
children.definition: Study of the body structures (anatomy) and life functions and activities (physiology)of plants and animals.

children.label: endocrinology
children.definition: Study of the collection of ductless glands that secrete hormones which influence growth, gender, sexual maturity, and other attributes.

children.label: histology
children.definition: Branch of anatomy concerned with the microscopic structure of plant and animal tissue.

children.label: immunology
children.definition: Branch of biology which studies the body's production of lymphocytes, antibodies, and macrophages in response to foreign substances or pathogenic organisms.

children.label: aquatic biology
children.definition: The scientific study of organisms living in or near water.  This term is to be used for the science of 'aquatic biology' and for  biological studies in fresh and brackish water. For marine biological studies, use 'marine biology'.

children.label: biochemistry
children.definition: Study of chemical processes that occur within or are mediated by living organisms.

children.label: botany
children.definition: The science of plants.

children.label: palynology
children.definition: Branch of botany concerned with the study of pollen and spores, especially fossil remains. These are used to study plant life and dispersal in geologic history and to date deposits.

children.label: phycology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of algae.

children.label: cell biology
children.definition: Branch of biology that deals with the study of the formation, structure, and physiology of cells.

children.label: developmental biology
children.definition: Scientific study of the processes related to the transformation of living organisms from single cells to complex multi-celled individuals.

children.label: ecology
children.definition: Study of the relations between living plants and animals and their environment.

children.label: ecotoxicology
children.definition: Scientific study of causes, dispersal, and effects of contaminants on the environment.

children.label: genetics
children.definition: Branch of biology that deals with heredity or the passing of traits in living organisms from one generation to the next.

children.label: marine biology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the organisms and habitats of the seas and oceans.

children.label: microbiology
children.definition: Branch of biology dealing with organisms too small to be seen without the use of a microscope.

children.label: bacteriology
children.definition: Study of the single celled microorganisms known as bacteria.

children.label: virology
children.definition: Branch of biology dealing with viruses and viral diseases.

children.label: molecular biology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of physiology at the molecular level.

children.label: morphology (biological)
children.definition: The scientific study of the form, shape, and structure of plants and animals and their fossil remains.

children.label: mycology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of fungi.

children.label: parasitology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of organisms that, living on or in another organism, take nutrition from the host and often harm it.

children.label: pathology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of the causes, progress, symptoms, diagnosis, and effects of diseases.

children.label: systematics and taxonomy
children.definition: Study of the identification, naming, and classification of organisms.

children.label: zoology
children.definition: Branch of biology that deals with the reproduction, development and growth, anatomy, physiology, and behavior of animals.

children.label: invertebrate zoology
children.definition: Branch of biology dealing with animals having no backbones or spinal columns.

children.label: entomology
children.definition: Branch of zoology involved in studying insects.

children.label: vertebrate zoology
children.definition: Branch of zoology that deals with animals that have spinal columns.

children.label: herpetology
children.definition: Branch of zoology concerned with the study of reptiles and amphibians.

children.label: ichthyology
children.definition: Branch of zoology concerned with the study of fish.

children.label: mammalogy
children.definition: Branch of zoology concerned with the study of mammals.

children.label: ornithology
children.definition: Branch of biology concerned with the study of birds.

children.label: wildlife biology
children.definition: Branch of biology dealing with living organisms, usually mammals, birds, or fishes, that are not domesticated or dependent on man.

children.label: ethology
children.definition: Study of animal behavior under natural conditions

children.label: planetary sciences
children.definition: Scientific study of the solid bodies of the solar system, including planets, moons, asteroids, meteorites, and interplanetary materials.

children.label: social sciences
children.definition: Sciences concerned with the structure and interrelationships of human societies, human institutions and organizations, and human culture over time.

children.label: archeology
children.definition: Study of human cultures through the recovery and analysis of their material relics.

label: topics
definition: Themes, subjects, and concerns for which USGS information resources are relevant.

children.label: agriculture
children.definition: The science and business of soil cultivation to raise crops and of animal husbandry to raise domesticated animals.

children.label: aquaculture
children.definition: The farming of organisms that live in water, such as fish, shellfish, and algae for human use.

children.label: biological and physical processes
children.definition: All continuing activities, functions, and phenomena associated with organisms and non-living matter.

children.label: atmospheric and climatic processes
children.definition: Phenomena affecting or occurring within the mass of gases that surrounds the earth, including its physics, chemistry, dynamics, and weather conditions.

children.label: atmospheric circulation
children.definition: Movement of atmospheric gases around the earth.

children.label: atmospheric deposition (chemical & particulate)
children.definition: The transfer of substances from the air to the surface of the earth, either in wet form (rain, fog, snow, dew, frost, hail) or in dry form (gases, aerosols, particles).

children.label: acid deposition
children.definition: The process by which emissions, chiefly sulfur and nitrogen compounds, either react with the atmosphere when deposited on earth by precipitation of snow, rain, or fog with a pH of 5.5 or below, or settle out as acidic particles or gases.

children.label: climate change
children.definition: Long-term alteration in the characteristic weather conditions of a region, such as changes in precipitation and temperature.

children.label: desertification
children.definition: The alteration of arable land to dry, barren land due to prolonged drought or the deleterious effects of human intervention including overgrazing, overpopulation, or destructive agricultural practices.

children.label: droughts
children.definition: Extended periods of moisture deficit over a sizeable area sufficient to have an adverse effect on vegetation, animals, or man.

children.label: ocean-atmosphere interaction
children.definition: Processes, including momentum, heat, gas and other exchanges, which result in profound effects on climate and interactions between the air in the lowest part of the atmosphere and the oceans.

children.label: El Nino-Southern Oscillation
children.definition: A roughly periodic variation in Pacific ocean sea-surface temperature causing changes in weather world-wide.

children.label: precipitation (atmospheric)
children.definition: Any or all forms of water particles that fall from the atmosphere, such as rain, snow, hail and sleet.

children.label: storms
children.definition: Atmospheric disturbances with winds of unusual force or direction. Accompanied by rain, snow, hail, or sleet, and often by thunder and lightning.

children.label: blizzards
children.definition: Severe snowstorms with intense winds.

children.label: hurricanes
children.definition: Severe cyclones, or revolving storms, originating over the equatorial regions of the earth, accompanied by torrential rain, lightning, and winds with a speed greater than 74 miles per hour.

children.label: ice storms
children.definition: Storms in which falling snow or rain freezes on contact with surfaces on the ground.

children.label: tornadoes
children.definition: Violent storms characterized by whirling funnels of wind moving at great speeds.

children.label: dust storms
children.definition: Atmospheric disturbances in which a significant amount of dust is transported.

children.label: evaporation
children.definition: Transfer of water from a surface into the atmosphere.

children.label: wind
children.definition: Local air movements.

children.label: greenhouse effect
children.definition: Local, regional, or global warming in the atmosphere due to the higher heat capacity of certain gases such as carbon dioxide, methane, and ozone.

children.label: ecological processes
children.definition: Dynamic biogeochemical interactions that occur among and between biotic and abiotic components of the biosphere.

children.label: algal blooms
children.definition: Exceptional growth of algae and cyanobacteria in lakes, rivers or oceans due to excessive nutrients or climatic conditions.

children.label: bioaccumulation
children.definition: The biological sequestering of a substance at a higher concentration than that at which it occurs in the surrounding environment or medium.  Also, the process whereby a substance enters an organism through the gills, epithelial tissues, dietary, or other sources.

children.label: biogeochemical cycling
children.definition: The cycling of chemical constituents through a biological system.

children.label: carbon cycling
children.definition: The circulation of carbon in the biosphere, atmosphere, and hydrosphere through a series of processes that include photosynthesis, consumption, and respiration.

children.label: nutrient cycling
children.definition: The exchange of elements or compounds essential for the nourishment of organisms in an ecosystem.

children.label: food web
children.definition: The complex intertwining of the interrelated food chains in an ecosystem.

children.label: biological productivity
children.definition: The rate at which primary producers in the ecosystem utilize solar energy to produce food for consumption by other organisms. Do not use this term for productivity of organisms related to studies of the reproduction rates of a species.

children.label: contaminant transport
children.definition: Processes involved in the movement of impurities through air, water, and soil.

children.label: dispersal (organisms)
children.definition: The dissemination or geographic spread of individuals of a plant or animal population.

children.label: ecological competition
children.definition: The struggle between members of two or more species for scarce environmental resources.

children.label: ecosystem functions
children.definition: The total life activities of organisms in habitats and the effects of those activities on the nonliving components of the environment.

children.label: wetland functions
children.definition: Processes related to wetlands such as support of ecosystems, evaporation effects on weather, nutrient cycles, etc.

children.label: eutrophication
children.definition: The process by which water becomes enriched with plant nutrients, most commonly phosphorus and nitrogen.

children.label: extinction and extirpation
children.definition: Extinction is the complete disappearance of a species from the earth.  Extirpation is the complete disappearance (elimination) of a species from a given region, island, or area.

children.label: habitat alteration and disturbance
children.definition: Changes in the environments where plants and animals live.  Includes natural changes as well as results of human actions, deliberate or accidental.

children.label: fire damage
children.definition: Destruction of surficial materials and vegetation by burning.

children.label: migration (organisms)
children.definition: The movement of animals, often periodical, from one area to another due to seasonal changes, availability of food, or climatic conditions.

children.label: pollination
children.definition: Wind, bees, or other agents transfer plant pollen from flower anthers or cones to stigmas, thereby fertilizing plants for reproduction.

children.label: succession (biological)
children.definition: Gradual replacement of one species in an area by another.

children.label: transpiration
children.definition: Evaporation of water from plants.

children.label: carbon flux
children.definition: The rate and amount of carbon exchanged between the oceans, atmosphere, land, and living things.

children.label: ecosystem resilience
children.definition: Measure of the persistence of systems and of their ability to absorb change and disturbance and still maintain the same relationships between populations or state variables. (Holling, 1973)

children.label: fires
children.definition: Combustion, marked by flames or intense heat, in natural settings, often ignited by lightning or human activities.  For fires set as part of natural resource management, use 'controlled fires'.

children.label: geochemical processes
children.definition: Processes affecting the amount, distribution, or structure of chemical elements in air, water, soil, rocks, and minerals.

children.label: biodegradation
children.definition: Reduction in the concentration of harmful chemicals by the action of animals and plants.

children.label: ore formation
children.definition: Geochemical processes resulting in concentration of useful chemical elements and compounds, in earth materials.  Typically refers to metal ores.

children.label: oxidation and reduction
children.definition: Addition or reduction of oxygen in a compound accompanied by exchange of electrons among atoms.

children.label: reaction transport
children.definition: Chemical reactions occurring during ground-water flow.

children.label: sorption
