children.definition: Attachment of chemical substances to materials, either externally (by adsorption) or internally (by absorption).

children.label: carbon sequestration
children.definition: Long-term storage of carbon in soils and terrestrial organic material, either by natural or engineered processes. Typically of importance for the balance of CO2 in the global climate system.

children.label: carbon mineralization
children.definition: A form of geologic carbon dioxide storage in which it reacts with rocks and minerals to form solid and stable carbonate materials.  Includes mineralization in mafic and ultramafic bedrock, mine tailings, and alkaline industrial wastes at the surface.

children.label: ocean acidification
children.definition: Decrease in the pH of ocean waters as a result of the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration.

children.label: thermal maturation
children.definition: Chemical alteration of organic material within sediments and sedimentary rocks as a result of heat. Measures of thermal maturation indicate the extent of transformation of detrital organic material into coal and petroleum.

children.label: geologic processes
children.definition: All types of processes involving geological structures.

children.label: diagenesis
children.definition: Chemical, physical, and biological changes in sediment during and after its conversion to rock (lithification).

children.label: earthquakes
children.definition: Ground shaking caused by the sudden release of accumulated strain by an abrupt shift of rock along a fracture in the earth or by volcanic or magmatic activity, or other sudden stress changes in the earth.

children.label: earthquake occurrences
children.definition: Time, location, severity, and mechanism of earthquake events, including the frequency and history of events in a given area.

children.label: induced seismicity
children.definition: Seismic activity such as earthquakes and tremors of low magnitude resulting from human activity that altered crustal stresses and strains on local faults and fractures.

children.label: ground failure
children.definition: Any consequences of shaking, including liquefaction, landslide, and lateral spread, that affects the stability of the ground.

children.label: liquefaction
children.definition: Physical process which can occur during an earthquake.  Clay-free soil deposits (primarily sands and silts)temporarily lose strength and behave as viscuous fluids, resulting in ground failure.

children.label: erosion
children.definition: The process whereby materials of the earth's crust are loosened, dissolved, or worn away and simultaneously moved from one place to another.

children.label: sinkhole formation
children.definition: Localized collapse of the land surface usually due to erosion of the underlying materials.  Most commonly occurring in karst areas, but similar effects occur due to physical erosion in other terranes.

children.label: glaciation
children.definition: The geologic processes involved in the formation, movement, changes, and effects of large ice masses (glaciers).

children.label: heat flow (earth)
children.definition: Energy transferred by a difference in temperature through the surface of the earth.

children.label: hydrothermal processes
children.definition: Natural phenomena relating to heated water generated by igneous activity.

children.label: isostasy
children.definition: Condition of equilibrium or buoyancy of the earth's crust above the mantle.

children.label: subsidence
children.definition: Settling, compaction, or caving in of land caused by subsurface mining, ground-water withdrawal, or pumping of oil and gas.

children.label: metamorphism (geological)
children.definition: Process by which rocks are altered in composition and texture by extreme heat, high pressure, or the action of chemicals.

children.label: alteration
children.definition: Local changes in the mineralogy of a rock body due to low-grade metamorphism, weathering, or both.  May indicate underlying mineral deposits.

children.label: sediment transport
children.definition: Transport of solid particles of unconsolidated rock and mineral fragments, chemical precipitates, or biological materials.

children.label: sedimentation
children.definition: Process of deposition of sediments (loose, uncemented pieces of rock, mineral fragments, or biological materials).  The sediments settle out of water or air into layers on a surface.

children.label: tectonic processes
children.definition: The structural forces affecting the deformation, uplift, and movement of the earth's crust.

children.label: neotectonic processes
children.definition: Changes which took place during geological time after the Miocene era and are associated with the structural forces that affect the deformation, uplift, and movement occurring in the earth's crust.

children.label: volcanic activity
children.definition: Episodes during which gases, ash, and lava (molten rock) escape from vents in the earth's crust, accompanied by minor tremors.

children.label: volcanic gas emission
children.definition: Emission of gases from fumaroles and volcanoes.

children.label: earth tides
children.definition: Periodic changes in the earth surface topography caused by the gravitational attraction of the moon and sun, measured with tiltmeters.  Used in studies of volcanic activity.

children.label: deformation (geologic)
children.definition: Change in form and structure of geologic materials in response to stress, typically heat and pressure.

children.label: folding (geologic)
children.definition: A property of geologic structures to bend or curve from the planar layers.

children.label: fracture (geologic)
children.definition: Break in a geologic structure including cracks, joints, and faults.

children.label: faulting (geologic)
children.definition: Movement of earth materials along fracture surfaces.

children.label: soil formation
children.definition: Geological, geochemical, and ecological processes that work together to produce soils.

children.label: magnetic storms
children.definition: A period of time during which the earth's magnetic field varies rapidly.  During magnetic storms, satellite electronics can be damaged through the build up and subsequent discharge of static electric charges and astronauts and high-altitude pilots can be subjected to increased levels of radiation.

children.label: slope processes
children.definition: The down slope movement of earth material under the influence of gravity.

children.label: landslides
children.definition: Downslope movement of rock, soil, or artificial fill under the influences of gravity.

children.label: lahars
children.definition: Downslope flow of ash and rock debris resulting from volcanic activity.

children.label: uplift
children.definition: Local or regional rise in the elevation of the land surface, usually due to tectonic or volcanic processes.

children.label: fluid migration
children.definition: Movement or migration of fluids, including petroleum and other chemicals through earth materials by natural or anthropogenic forces.

children.label: ocean processes
children.definition: Recurrent natural changes that are physical, biological, or chemical, actively affecting the seas and oceans.

children.label: ocean circulation
children.definition: Movement of large masses of water within an ocean.

children.label: ocean currents
children.definition: Recurrent strong flows of seawater generated by wind or variations in water density along a given path.

children.label: ocean waves
children.definition: A periodic movement of seawater caused by wind, tide, and currents.

children.label: tsunamis
children.definition: Sea waves generated by submarine earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, or landslides, which are generally imperceptible in deep water but may be very destructive when striking the shoreline.

children.label: tides (oceanic)
children.definition: The periodic rise and fall of the level of the sea due to the gravitational attraction of the moon and sun. Occurs twice each day.

children.label: physiological processes
children.definition: Characteristics and processes of individual organisms that are not the direct result of their interaction with other organisms or with the environment.

children.label: organism growth and development
children.definition: Changes that living things undergo as they progress from inception as a single cell to adult forms.

children.label: metamorphosis
children.definition: Transformation in animals, such as amphibians and insects, from one developmental stage to another.

children.label: anatomical deformities
children.definition: Physical malformation of organisms typically resulting from exposure to contaminants, disease, or adverse environmental conditions.

children.label: bioluminescence
children.definition: Emission of light by organisms.

children.label: osmosis
children.definition: Transfer of substances through biological membranes.

children.label: photosynthesis
children.definition: Conversion of sunlight, water, and nutrients into energy by plants.

children.label: bioenergetics
children.definition: Processes by which a living organism acquires, produces, utilizes, or transforms energy.

children.label: floods
children.definition: Relatively high water that overflows the natural or artificial banks of a stream or coastal area that submerges land not normally below water level.

children.label: storm surge
children.definition: Coastal high water level caused by wind from storms.

children.label: groundwater flow
children.definition: Movement of subsurface water in the saturated zone from areas of recharge to areas of discharge.

children.label: streamflow
children.definition: A type of channel flow, applied to a specific part of surface runoff in a stream, whether or not it is affected by diversion or regulation.

children.label: stream discharge
children.definition: Volume of water in a stream passing a given point at a given moment in time, expressed as a measure of volume per unit of time, i.e. cubic feet per second, million gallons per day, or gallons per minute.

children.label: turbidity
children.definition: Cloudiness in the water column, caused by the presence of suspended and dissolved matter such as clay, silt, organic matter, or plankton.

children.label: water circulation
children.definition: The flow of water in a body of water due to wind or other forces or variations in density or temperature. Use 'water circulation' for situations that are not specifically covered by narrower terms. Use 'ocean circulation' for water circulation in the oceans.

children.label: water cycle
children.definition: Interchange of water among land, oceans, and atmosphere.

children.label: percolation
children.definition: The movement of water through fractures or interstices of a rock or soil.

children.label: runoff
children.definition: Flow of water over land surfaces (including paved surfaces), typically from precipitation.

children.label: saltwater intrusion
children.definition: Infusion of saline waters in an aquifer or body of surface water.

children.label: scour
children.definition: Erosion of sediment in a stream bed, often occurring at manmade structures such as bridge supports.

children.label: groundwater and surface-water interaction
children.definition: Traditionally, management of water resources has focused on surface water or groundwater as if they were separate entities. As development of land and water resources increases, it is apparent that development of either of these resources affects the quantity and quality of the other. Nearly all surface-water features (streams, lakes, reservoirs, wetlands, and estuaries) interact with groundwater. These interactions take many forms. In many situations, surface-water bodies gain water and solutes from groundwater systems and in others the surface-water body is a source of groundwater recharge and causes changes in groundwater quality. As a result, withdrawal of water from streams can deplete groundwater or conversely, pumpage of groundwater can deplete water in streams, lakes, or wetlands. Pollution of surface water can cause degradation of groundwater quality and conversely pollution of groundwater can degrade surface water.

children.label: evolution
children.definition: Change in the genetic composition of populations of living organisms.

children.label: impact cratering
children.definition: Impact of extraterrestrial objects such as asteroids, comets, and meteorites on Earth.

children.label: coastal processes
children.definition: Processes unique to coastal areas including longshore transport, beach erosion, storm surge, shoreline change, delta formation, barrier island migration, beach stabilization by vegetation

children.label: longshore currents
children.definition: Movement of water parallel to the coast due to waves striking the shoreline at an angle

children.label: tidal currents
children.definition: Currents caused by tidal changes in water level from one body of water to another.

children.label: barrier island migration
children.definition: The slow, landward movement of barrier islands in response to sea level rise and repeated storm washover.

children.label: coastal emergence
children.definition: Relative uplift of the coast accompanied by seaward displacement of the shoreline.

children.label: coastal submergence
children.definition: Relative subsidence of the coast accompanied by landward displacement of the shoreline.

children.label: shoreline accretion
children.definition: Seaward migration of the shoreline resulting from the addition of earth materials.

children.label: estuarine processes
children.definition: Processes affecting estuaries including tides, waves, mixing of fluvial and marine waters

children.label: estuarine currents
children.definition: Movement of water within estuaries due to the complex interaction of winds, tides, and variations in water density

children.label: estuarine mixing
children.definition: Interaction of tidal forcing and river discharge in an estuary, leading to any of three vertical salinity profiles: salt wedge, stratified, or well mixed. We also include mixing due to extreme events such as storm surge.

children.label: hydrocarbon reservoir processes
children.definition: Interactions among groundwater, hydrocarbons, and rock properties of subsurface geological formations, affecting the potential of those formations to form, trap, and permit the passage and extraction of hydrocarbons.

children.label: culture and demographics
children.definition: Information on human behavior, ways of living and thinking, and characteristics of human populations.

children.label: administrative and political boundaries
children.definition: Lines drawn on maps or described in documents which encompass territory controlled by a government or organizational unit that may or may not align with geographic or cultural barriers. Use for datasets containing boundary representations for political/administrative units and related information.

children.label: protected areas
children.definition: Terrestrial and marine areas that are designated and managed for the preservation of biological diversity or other natural, recreational, or cultural uses.

children.label: business and economics
children.definition: The activities and processes associated with the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

children.label: recycling
children.definition: Physical processes by which previously-used materials are converted from scrap and waste to reusable forms.

children.label: resource supply and demand
children.definition: Statistics indicating the commercial interests in material resources, typically mineral commodities, energy, or forest or fishery resources.

children.label: materials flow (commodities)
children.definition: Industrial and commercial processes by which material resources are extracted, used or consumed, and disposed or recycled.

children.label: cadastral and legal land descriptions
children.definition: Records in official registers showing extent, boundaries, and ownerships of land for administration and taxation.

children.label: laws and regulations
children.definition: Legal statements of the government regarding actions people or corporations might undertake.

children.label: transportation
children.definition: Movement of people or materials from one place to another for economic, political, or recreational purposes.

children.label: geographic names
children.definition: Names by which cultural and geographic features are known.  Generally to be used for collections of names stored in gazetteers.

children.label: population (human)
children.definition: Geographic distribution and temporal trends of human habitation in specific areas

children.label: earth characteristics
children.definition: The measurable, definable properties and features of the earth.

children.label: atmospheric properties
children.definition: Characteristics of the mass of gases surrounding the earth  such as composition, temperature, pressure, and humidity.

children.label: atmospheric composition
children.definition: Components of the mass of gases that surrounds a planet.  The earth's atmosphere consists of nitrogen, oxygen, and small portions of other gases.

children.label: greenhouse gases
children.definition: Atmospheric gases, including carbon dioxide, fluorocarbons, methane, nitrous oxide, sulfur hexafluoride, ozone, and water vapor, that trap radiant (infrared) energy keeping the earth's surface warmer than it would otherwise be.

children.label: ozone layer
children.definition: Upper atmosphere layer composed of ozone, a gas made up of molecules comprised of three oxygen atoms, which helps to shield the earth from ultraviolet rays.

children.label: earth structure
children.definition: Major interior structural features of the planet earth.

children.label: core (earth)
children.definition: The superdense center of the earth composed of two layers: a liquid outer layer and a solid inner core of metallic iron-nickel alloy.

children.label: inner core (earth)
children.definition: The solid interior part of the earth's core, presumed to be composed principally of iron with an alloy of about 10 percent oxygen, sulfur, or nickel, or perhaps some combination of these three elements.  The inner core is about 1221 kilometers thick.

children.label: outer core (earth)
children.definition: Outer zone of the earth's core between the mantle and the inner core.

children.label: crust (earth)
children.definition: The outermost layer of the earth which is relatively thin, of lower density than the core, and rocky.

children.label: lithosphere
children.definition: The solid outer zone of the earth comprising the crust and the upper layer of the mantle.

children.label: continental lithosphere
children.definition: The earth's hard, outermost shell comprised of the crust and the upper part of the mantle.

children.label: oceanic lithosphere
children.definition: The solid outer zone of the earth, covered by seawater, and comprised of the crust and the upper layer of the mantle.

children.label: mantle (earth)
children.definition: Zone of earth's interior between the crust and the core.  It is 2,900 kilometers (1,740 miles) thick and consists of a dense upper layer (upper mantle) and a partially molten lower layer (lower mantle), separated by a transition zone.

children.label: asthenosphere
children.definition: A layer of the earth within the upper mantle and directly below the lithosphere. This layer has a semi-solid consistency that reaches to about 200 kilometers (124 miles) below the surface.

children.label: geologic history
children.definition: Record (and inferred reconstruction) of the origin and development of the earth since its formation.

children.label: earth history
children.definition: The structural and compositional changes that the earth has undergone from its formation. Use for discussions of the whole earth (or large sections of it) instead of regional studies.

children.label: geologic structure
children.definition: General position of rocks in an area, and geometrical relationships among rocks.

children.label: foliation (geologic)
children.definition: The property of rocks or glaciers splitting into thin layers or plates due to the orientation of crystals and dynamic movement.

children.label: lineation (geologic)
children.definition: Linear topographic feature on the earth's surface or in rocks.

children.label: structure contours
children.definition: Gridding and contouring lines drawn on geologic maps to depict boundaries of structural features.

children.label: gravitational field (earth)
children.definition: Region or space around earth's mass which exerts a force that mutually attracts other masses in proportion to the product of the two masses and the distance between them.

children.label: isostatic anomaly
children.definition: Gravity anomaly corrected for the effects of low-density rocks underlying mountains.

children.label: free-air anomaly
children.definition: Gravity anomaly corrected for elevation of the location at which the measurements were made.

children.label: bouguer anomaly
children.definition: Gravity anomaly corrected to remove the effects of topography using knowledge of the terrain in the area surrounding the measurement station.

children.label: gravity gradient
children.definition: Lateral variation of the three-dimensional vector components of gravity, typically measured using airborne sensors.

children.label: land surface characteristics
children.definition: Features and attributes of earth's land surface.

children.label: karst
children.definition: Landscape characterized by dissolution features in carbonate or evaporite terranes, often containing caves and sinkholes.

children.label: magnetic field (earth)
children.definition: The magnetic region surrounding earth.  It is generated by the dipolar characteristic of earth's core whereby earth itself acts as a great spherical magnet with poles near, but not exactly at, the North and South poles.

children.label: ocean characteristics
children.definition: The attributes and process of seas and oceans.

children.label: ocean salinity
children.definition: Measure of the percentage of dissolved salts in seawater.

children.label: ocean temperature
children.definition: Distribution of heat in the oceans, including surface water, thermocline and mode waters, and deep waters.  Includes discussion and measures of both in-situ and potential temperature.

children.label: sea surface temperature
children.definition: Observed temperature of surface ocean waters, typically encompassing the entire mixed layer. Some observational methods, however, may measure a much smaller depth range.  Includes temperature data obtained in-situ or by remote sensing methods.

children.label: sea-floor characteristics
children.definition: Geomorphic features and geographic, compositional, and textural variation in the materials composing the ocean floor. Includes both large-scale structures (such as seamounts and rises) and fine-scale variations in rocks and deposits on the sea floor.

children.label: sea-floor acoustic reflectivity
children.definition: Acoustic energy received by a sonar system, providing a measure of the roughness of the sea floor.

children.label: sea-level change
children.definition: Variation in the relative vertical position of land and ocean waters. Caused globally by changes in the distribution of ice masses and the shape of the oceans, and locally by the rate of uplift or subsidence of the land surface.  Includes both global (eustatic) and local (relative) sea-level variations.

children.label: rocks and deposits
children.definition: Solid masses that make up the earth's crust as well as accumulations of materials. Use for major rock types and unconsolidated deposits. For deposits of economic value, see related terms.

children.label: fossils
children.definition: Recognizable remains such as bones, shells, leaves, burrows, impressions, or tracks of past life on the earth.

children.label: ichnofossils
children.definition: Fossilized remains of the traces of animal activity from different geologic time periods including burrows, tracks, trails, borings, and other features found in sedimentary structures.

children.label: igneous rocks
children.definition: Rocks formed from melted rock that has cooled and solidified.

children.label: volcanic rocks
children.definition: A generally finely crystalline or glassy igneous rock resulting from volcanic action at or near the earth's surface, either ejected explosively or extruded as lava. The term includes near-surface intrusions that form a part of the volcanic structure.

children.label: plutonic rocks
children.definition: Rocks formed at considerable depth by crystallization of magma and/or by chemical alteration. They are characteristically medium- to coarse-grained, of granitoid texture.

children.label: metamorphic rocks
children.definition: Sedimentary or igneous rocks which have undergone such intense changes in temperature, pressure, structural stress, or chemical environment that they are transformed into denser rocks.

children.label: sedimentary rocks
children.definition: Rocks formed by the consolidation of loose, uncemented pieces of sediments.

children.label: bedforms
children.definition: Fluctuations from horizontal layers in sediments or sedimentary rocks made by flow on the beds of alluvial channels.

children.label: unconsolidated deposits
children.definition: Loosely bound sediments such as sand, gravel, and silt which tend to accumulate in low areas or valleys.

children.label: clay deposits
children.definition: Fine-grained sedimentary soil deposits, containing hydrated silicas of aluminum, that are plastic and sticky when wet and harden when heated.

children.label: gravel deposits
children.definition: Alluvial accumulations of small unconsolidated rock fragments, such as pebbles and cobbles, used in construction as fill, ground cover, or aggregate for concrete.

children.label: sand deposits
children.definition: Deposits of loose particles of rock or mineral (sediment) that range in size from 0.0625-2.0 millimeters in diameter.

children.label: mine waste
children.definition: Earth materials removed during mining and concentrated in piles or beds, typically near the site of extraction.  Tailings are mine waste that has been processed to remove valuable components; unprocessed mine waste includes overburden removed to reach commodity materials such as ore or coal.

children.label: soil horizons
children.definition: Layers in soil defined by physical, chemical, biological, or mineralogical properties which vary with depth.

children.label: solid industrial waste material
children.definition: Waste solid materials produced by industrial processing of earth materials, not simply material extracted in the search for ores.

children.label: slag
children.definition: Solid waste material produced by the industrial processing of ore materials.

children.label: coal ash
children.definition: Solid waste material remaining from the burning of coal.

children.label: permafrost
children.definition: Rocks and deposits in which the interstitial waters remain perennially frozen.

children.label: petroleum
children.definition: Naturally occurring hydrocarbons, typically fluid or gas, often of economic use.  Includes oil, natural gas, and asphaltic compounds found in tar sands and oil shales.

children.label: mineral deposits
children.definition: Deposits in which particular minerals are concentrated, typically noticed and studied if the minerals have economic value.

children.label: snow and ice cover
children.definition: Accumulation of snow or ice blanketing land surfaces.

children.label: sea ice concentration
children.definition: Proportion of ocean area in a given region that contains or is covered by floating ice.

children.label: stratigraphic sections
children.definition: Vertical arrangement in layers of rock units whose sequence is used to study the geological history of the strata.

children.label: bedrock geologic units
children.definition: Units of consolidated (solid) rock that underlie soils or other unconsolidated materials.

children.label: geologic contacts
children.definition: Junctions of two different rock formations varying by type or age of rock, including faults, unconformities, and bedding planes.

children.label: unconformities
children.definition: The contact between older rocks and younger sedimentary rocks where erosion had removed some of the older rocks before the younger rocks were deposited.

children.label: surficial geologic units
children.definition: Rock units on the earth's surface.

children.label: stratigraphic thickness
children.definition: Thickness of earth material layers or groups of such layers, often portrayed as isopachs (contours) or gridded data.

children.label: topography
children.definition: Configuration of the land surface and sea floor.

children.label: bathymetry
children.definition: The elevation of the earth's surface beneath a body of water, especially the ocean, typically determined by measurements of depth from the water surface.

children.label: earth material properties
children.definition: Physical characteristics of rocks and unconsolidated earth materials such as soils and sediments.

children.label: permeability
children.definition: The ability of fluids to pass through an earth material, typically depending on the connectedness of pore space in the material.

children.label: porosity
children.definition: The proportion of open space in a rock or unconsolidated material.

children.label: radioactivity
children.definition: Release of subatomic particles from earth materials.  Generally the energy of these particles is used to determine the chemical elements present.

children.label: resistivity
children.definition: Electrical resistance of materials, often measured in boreholes.

children.label: bulk density
children.definition: Overall density of an unconsolidated earth material.

children.label: magnetism
children.definition: Strength and orientation of the permanent magnetic field in a given sample of an earth material

children.label: remanent magnetism
children.definition: Magnetic characteristic of rocks and deposits reflective of the earth's magnetic field at the time of the deposit's formation.

children.label: magnetic susceptibility
children.definition: Degree to which a rock type or other earth material can acquire and retain the orientation and intensity of an applied magnetic field.

children.label: soil moisture
children.definition: Water content of soil and other near-surface unconsolidated earth material

children.label: soil temperature
children.definition: Temperature and temperature gradients in soil and other near-surface unconsolidated earth materials

children.label: acid neutralizing potential
children.definition: Geochemical capacity of earth materials to affect the pH of waters flowing through them.

children.label: electromagnetic reflectance and emissivity
children.definition: Effectiveness of an earth material in reflecting or emitting radiation, varying by wavelength.  Measurements are made over the infrared part of the electromagnetic spectrum in a laboratory to compare with remotely-sensed data obtained by airborne or satellite imaging systems.

children.label: lakebed characteristics
children.definition: Characteristics of the bottom of inland bodies of water.

children.label: lakebed acoustic reflectivity
children.definition: Acoustic energy received by a sonar system, providing a measure of the roughness of the lakebed.

children.label: effects of climate change
children.definition: Characteristics and behaviors of organisms and earth systems that are modified as a result of changes in global, regional, or local climate.

children.label: hazards
children.definition: Potential dangers from both natural processes (e.g., earthquakes, floods, and climate change) and human impacts on the environment.

children.label: health and disease
children.definition: Normal and abnormal conditions of plant and animal bodies.  Covers both human and non-human health and disease topics. For human health and disease, use the narrower term 'environmental health (human)'.

children.label: disease vectors
children.definition: Organisms, such as insects, that transmit pathogens from one host to another.

children.label: environmental health (human)
children.definition: Effects of the environment on human health.

children.label: human environmental safety
children.definition: Monitoring and managing potentially harmful factors in the environment for human safety.

children.label: zoonotic diseases
children.definition: Diseases of animals that can be communicated to humans

children.label: wildlife disease
children.definition: Includes viral, bacterial, and fungal infections as well as exposure of organisms to dangerous chemicals or toxic substances.

children.label: avian influenza
children.definition: A virulent disease of poultry and wild birds that has spread throughout a large geographic area in Asia and Eastern Europe since it was first documented in 1997 in Asia.

children.label: chronic wasting disease
children.definition: Transmissible neurological disease of deer and elk that produces small lesions in the brains of infected animals; may be transmitted to humans who consume the meat of infected animals.

children.label: white-nose syndrome
children.definition: Disease affecting hibernating bats caused by a white fungus infecting the skin of the muzzle, ears, and wings

children.label: human impacts
children.definition: The effects, intentional or unintentional, beneficial or harmful, direct or indirect, which human activities have upon the environment and living things.

children.label: land use change
children.definition: Effect of changing land use patterns on ecological systems.

children.label: habitat fragmentation
children.definition: Disruption of once-continuous natural habitats by human activities such as agriculture, urbanization, resource extraction, and the construction of roads, railways, fences, and pipelines.

children.label: mining hazards
children.definition: Dangerous conditions which result from the extraction of naturally occurring mineral deposits.  Includes tunnel collapses, fires, and explosions.

children.label: overfishing
children.definition: Taking too many fish from an area beyond the capacity for the population to replenish its numbers. The balance of the ecosystem is upset, leading to long-term depletion of fish stock.

children.label: overgrazing
children.definition: The practice of allowing animals to eat vegetation, especially ground cover, beyond the capacity of the plant population to replenish itself. Leads to erosion and other harm to the ecosystem.

children.label: waste treatment and disposal
children.definition: The chemical and physical methods to recycle or dispose of materials which, without treatment, are deemed to have no further value or are too contaminated to be used.

children.label: deforestation
children.definition: Reduction in the density of forest cover or tree canopy, typically by harvesting trees for human use or clearing land for other purposes such as agriculture.

children.label: dredging
children.definition: Removal of sediments from water bodies to aid navigation or to transfer material to another location.

children.label: abandoned mines and quarries
children.definition: Mines and quarries that have been abandoned and may expose harmful chemicals to the environment.

children.label: information system design and development
children.definition: Use for the design and development of information systems.  Do not use for general cases in which information systems are part of the activity.

children.label: geographic information systems
children.definition: Computer software that allows geospatially referenced data to be linked to geographic features. Use this term only for information that is about GIS and not for the use of GIS in applications and projects.

children.label: metadata development
children.definition: Use for the development of metadata schemes and applications.  Do not use for general cases where metadata are part of the activities.

children.label: instrument design and development
children.definition: Includes the design and development of software for a particular instrument.

children.label: land use and land cover
children.definition: The vegetation, water, natural surface, and cultural features on the land surface.

children.label: map coordinate systems
children.definition: Systems using sets of numbers combined with geometric nets or grids to specific positions on a map or globe.

children.label: contamination and pollution
children.definition: Introduction of harmful substances into the environment by human action or natural processes.

children.label: pesticide and herbicide contamination
children.definition: Pollution resulting from chemical agents applied to crops, rights of way, lawns, or residences to control weeds, insects, fungi, nematodes, rodents or other pests (pesticides) or kill undesirable plants (herbicides).

children.label: toxic radionuclide contamination
children.definition: Introduction into the environment of unstable isotopes of elements that undergo radioactive decay, emitting radiation that is harmful to organisms.

children.label: toxic trace element contamination
children.definition: Introduction into the environment of elements (such as arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury) which have a deleterious effect on living organisms when found naturally in only minor amounts (concentrations less than 1.0 milligram per liter) in water or sediment.

children.label: mercury contamination
children.definition: Biological disturbances caused by mercury compounds that have entered the environment.

children.label: nonpoint-source pollution
children.definition: Contamination of the environment from sources spread widely across an area, not from a small number of identifiable locations.

children.label: pharmaceutical contamination
children.definition: Unintentional release of pharmaceutical compounds into the environment; work focuses on the effects of these compounds on organisms and water resources.

children.label: industrial pollution
children.definition: Introduction of harmful substances into the environment by manufacturing, power generation, mining, or material processing.

children.label: mine drainage
children.definition: Introduction of harmful substances into the environment from mines and tailings.

children.label: produced water
children.definition: Water produced during generation and development of energy resources, particularly hydrocarbons, as well as related fluids injected into reservoirs for energy development and associated waste disposal.

children.label: microplastic contamination
children.definition: Plastic particles less than 5 millimeters in diameter that come from a wide variety of sources, found in a variety of forms, including fibers, pellets/beads, foams, films, fragments, and tire particles, and reach aquatic environments through diverse pathways.

children.label: PFAS
children.definition: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a group of man-made chemical compounds that are an emerging contaminant.

children.label: natural resource exploration
children.definition: Techniques for locating deposits or stocks of useful minerals, water, and other resources using reconnaissance or instrumental methods.

children.label: natural resource extraction
children.definition: Removal of natural materials or properties (such as heat) for use.

children.label: mining and quarrying
children.definition: Extracting mineral deposits from a pit, tunnel, or excavation.

children.label: well drilling
children.definition: The process of artificial excavation for the purpose of withdrawing water, oil, or gas from underground.

children.label: placer deposit mining
children.definition: Extraction of minerals, typically metal ores, from unconsolidated surficial materials such as stream sediments.

children.label: enhanced oil recovery
children.definition: Injection of steam, gas, or other chemical compounds into hydrocarbon reservoirs to stimulate the production of usable oil beyond what is possible through natural pressure, water injection, and pumping at the wellhead.

children.label: hydraulic fracturing
children.definition: Injection of water and other fluids through a well into geologic formations in order to increase the permeability of the rock units and thus permit natural gas or oil to be produced from them.

children.label: natural resources
children.definition: Stocks of anything naturally occurring that have a beneficial use for man including economic, nutritional, recreational, aesthetic, and other benefits.

children.label: fishery resources
children.definition: The stock of anadromous, marine, and freshwater fish in fishing areas of commercial, subsistence, and recreational value.

children.label: commercial fishery resources
children.definition: Stocks of fish and other seafood used for marketing purposes.

children.label: inland fishery resources
children.definition: Stocks of fish available to be taken in lakes, streams, ponds, rivers, and other inland bodies of water.

children.label: marine fishery resources
children.definition: The stock of fisheries located in seas and oceans.

children.label: whaling
children.definition: Taking whales from the ocean for marketing or subsistence purposes.

children.label: recreational fishery resources
children.definition: The stock of fish and other seafood resources in areas used for recreational fishing.

children.label: subsistence fishery resources
children.definition: The stock of fish taken and eaten by local populations rather than marketed.

children.label: forest resources
children.definition: Trees and associated vegetation available for human use.  Use for timber and other forest resources with economic value.

children.label: mineral resources
children.definition: Natural occurrences of useful inorganic elements or compounds.

children.label: metallic mineral resources
children.definition: Resources from which ductile, malleable, opaque,and reflective metals that are also good heat and electricity conductors can be extracted.

children.label: nonmetallic mineral resources
children.definition: Useful mineral deposits that are not metals.  Includes materials used for construction, decoration, fuel, and industrial purposes.

children.label: building stone resources
children.definition: Deposits of rocks used in construction, including crushed stone and dimension stone. Dimension stone includes limestone and granite, quarried in large blocks, and shaped in cubes, panels and other forms.

children.label: gem resources
children.definition: Deposits of rare minerals prized for their color, durability, sparkle, and clarity when cut and polished and used as ornaments or jewelry.

children.label: critical minerals
children.definition: A non-fuel mineral or mineral material essential to the economic and national security of the US, the supply chain of which is vulnerable to disruption, and that serves an essential function in the manufacturing of a product, the absence of which would have significant consequences for our economy or our national security.

children.label: energy resources
children.definition: Natural resources that are used for heat and power generation, including oil, natural gas, coal, and geothermal energy.

children.label: coal resources
children.definition: Fuel resources such as anthracite, lignite, bituminous coal, or coke, consisting largely of carbonaceous material and formed from fossilized plants.

children.label: geothermal resources
children.definition: Energy resources related to the earth's internal heat, commonly applied to springs or vents discharging hot water or steam.

children.label: natural gas resources
children.definition: Stocks of naturally formed hydrocarbon gases which are usually associated with petroleum fields.  Useful for heating, they are principally methane, but can be ethane, butane, or propane.

children.label: coalbed methane resources
children.definition: Resources of methane-rich gas generated and stored in coalbeds.

children.label: gas hydrate resources
children.definition: Deposits of a crystalline solid in which water molecules trap gas molecules, usually methane, in a cagelike structure known as a clathrate occurring in sediments overlain by cold deep water.

children.label: oil resources
children.definition: Deposits (pools) of highly valuable liquid hydrocarbons or fossil fuels.

children.label: oil sand resources
children.definition: Deposits of sandstone or unconsolidated sand containing bitumen that can be extracted as an oil resource.

children.label: oil shale resources
children.definition: Deposits of finely grained sedimentary rock containing kerogen that can be distilled to produce liquid or gaseous hydrocarbons.

children.label: wind energy
children.definition: Use of prevailing wind as a source of energy to drive turbines or other machinery.

children.label: energy storage
children.definition: Methods and technologies for holding energy to be recovered at a later time.

children.label: geologic energy storage
children.definition: Use of subsurface reservoirs to store energy that can be recovered at a later time using thermal [energy], gravity, or stored air or natural gases.

children.label: soil resources
children.definition: Natural resources of unconsolidated fragmented rock, humus, and mineral matter that cover the surface of the earth.

children.label: biological soil crusts
children.definition: Communities commonly found on the soil surface in arid and semi-arid ecosystems, these consist of mosses, cyanobacteria, lichens, algae, and microfungi, which weave together and adhere to the soil to form a matrix that lessens erosion, supports nitrogen fixation, and retains moisture. These organisms are important to the functioning of ecosystems and to the organization of plant and soil communities.

children.label: water resources
children.definition: Stocks of water, the liquid derived from precipitation. A constituent of living matter and necessity for all life, it covers a large proportion of the earth's surface.

children.label: groundwater
children.definition: All water that exists beneath the land surface, but more commonly applied to water in fully saturated soils and geologic formations.

children.label: groundwater level
children.definition: Depth in a well or aquifer at which groundwater occurs.

children.label: unsaturated zone
children.definition: The portion of the subsurface above the ground water table.

children.label: surface water (non-marine)
children.definition: Open bodies of water, such as lakes, rivers, or streams.  All non-marine waters on the  surface of the earth, including fresh, brackish, and salt water.

children.label: river systems
children.definition: Long water courses including main streams and tributaries.

children.label: river reaches
children.definition: Continuous parts of streams between two specified points.

children.label: surface-water level
children.definition: Height of the water surface in a lake, reservoir, or wetland. For water levels in flowing streams, refer to streamflow.

children.label: organism groupings (non-taxonomic)
children.definition: Used for categories of living organisms that are not taxonomic and that include species from more than one taxonomic group.

children.label: biota
children.definition: All living organisms in an area.

children.label: consumers (organisms)
children.definition: Organisms unable to produce food from nonliving matter and dependent on ingesting other animals, plants, or particulate organic matter.

children.label: carnivores
children.definition: Flesh-eating animals.

children.label: herbivores
children.definition: Animals that eat chiefly plants or their products, such as seeds, nectar, and fruit.

children.label: omnivores
children.definition: Animals that eat both plant and animal materials.

children.label: decomposers
children.definition: Organisms, chiefly microorganisms and invertebrates, that feed on dead plant or animal matter breaking it down and recycling the resulting elements and compounds in the environment.

children.label: endangered species
children.definition: Plant or animal species reduced to such low numbers of individuals that they are at risk of becoming extinct.

children.label: game species
children.definition: Species of wild animals that are hunted for food or sport.

children.label: keystone species
children.definition: Species whose abundance and ecological role has a dramatic effect on the other species in an ecosystem.

children.label: macroinvertebrates
children.definition: Invertebrate animals large enough to be studied without a microscope.

children.label: migratory species
children.definition: Species that have a pattern of moving from one geographical area to another, primarily according to the seasons, and usually traveling long distances along established routes.

children.label: native species
children.definition: Organisms originating in the area where they live.

children.label: endemic species
children.definition: Plant and animals species native to and confined to specific geographic areas.

children.label: nekton
children.definition: Free-swimming aquatic organisms able to move without depending on waves, currents, and tides.

children.label: nonindigenous species
children.definition: Organisms accidentally or intentionally introduced into areas where they did not previously originate or live.

children.label: invasive species
children.definition: Plant, animal, or microbe species that is non-native (or alien) to the ecosystem under consideration and whose introduction causes or is likely to cause economic or environmental harm, or harm to human health.

children.label: plankton
children.definition: Floating aquatic plants (phytoplankton) and animals (zooplankton) which are often microscopic and drift with the current in lakes, rivers, and oceans.

children.label: phytoplankton
children.definition: Small, mostly microscopic aquatic plants such as algae and bacteria suspended in water.

children.label: pollinators
children.definition: Organisms that aid in the growth and distribution of plants by transferring pollen as a byproduct of their feeding activities.

children.label: producers (organisms)
children.definition: Organisms, chiefly green plants, which use inorganic elements, compounds, and light to produce their food (photosynthesis). They are a source of food for animals.

children.label: shellfish
children.definition: Aquatic invertebrates with shells, usually mollusks and crustaceans. Includes clams, lobsters, and oysters.

children.label: vegetation
children.definition: Plant life or general plant cover in an area.

children.label: periphyton
children.definition: A plant assemblage including microbial communities of algae and cyanobacteria living attached to submerged aquatic vegetation.

children.label: weeds
children.definition: Plants whose presence in an area is undesirable.

children.label: aquatic vegetation
children.definition: Plants living primarily in or under water.

children.label: wildlife
children.definition: Undomesticated organisms living in natural settings without dependence on man.

children.label: benthos
children.definition: Animals that live on the bottom of water bodies.

children.label: microbes
children.definition: Microscopic, typically one-celled organisms.

children.label: parasites
children.definition: Symbiotic organisms that are detrimental to the host.

children.label: nuisance species
children.definition: Organisms whose presence or behavior has undesirable effects on human activities.

children.label: genetically engineered organisms
children.definition: Organisms whose DNA has been modified through the insertion or deletion of DNA fragments from the same or another species, in order to produce or enhance desirable traits such as increased yield, resistance to pests, adaptation to drastically changed environments, or formation of entirely new compounds.

children.label: organisms
children.definition: Living individuals that grow, reproduce, and die.

children.label: algae
children.definition: Chlorophyll-bearing primarily aquatic nonvascular species that have no true roots, stems, or leaves; most algae are microscopic, but some species can be as large as vascular plants.

children.label: calcareous nannoplankton
children.definition: Organisms of the kingdom Protista that normally produce coccoliths, microscopic structures of calcite (calcium carbonate), during some phase of their life cycle.

children.label: diatoms
children.definition: Microscopic, single-celled plants of the class Bacillariophyceae that have siliceous shells called frustules, and which grow in both marine and fresh water.

children.label: dinoflagellates
children.definition: Single-celled planktonic organisms, chiefly marine, characterized by twirling motion and whip-like flagella with affinities to both plants and animals.

children.label: animals
children.definition: Multi-celled organisms of the kingdom Animalia with eukaryotic cells (cells with distinct nuclei containing genetic material and bounded by thin membranes) that are heterotrophic (obtaining energy from organic substances produced by other organisms).

children.label: invertebrates
children.definition: Animals having no backbone or spinal column, such as insects, mollusks, crustaceans, worms, and similar organisms.

children.label: arthropods
children.definition: Invertebrates belonging to the largest phylum of animals, Arthropoda, with an exoskeleton, segmented bodies, and jointed appendages, including many subphyla and classes, such as insects, crustaceans, horseshoe crabs, sea spiders, centipedes, millipedes, and the extinct trilobites.

children.label: arachnids
children.definition: Carnivorous arthropods, chiefly terrestrial, of the class Arachnida including spiders, scorpions, mites, ticks, false scorpions, palpigrades, solifugids, and harvestmen.

children.label: crustaceans
children.definition: Arthropods of class Crustacea, such as crabs, lobsters, shrimp, prawns, or barnacles, with hard shells (exoskeleton) and segmented bodies with pairs of jointed appendages.

children.label: ostracodes
children.definition: Small aquatic crustaceans belonging to the subclass Ostracoda, characterized by a bivalve shell.

children.label: horseshoe crabs
children.definition: Marine arthropods, usually classed as Merostomata, which have a broad crescent (horseshoe-shaped) cephalothorax.

children.label: insects
children.definition: Small arthropod animals of the class Insecta with bodies in 3 segments (head, thorax, and abdomen). They have 3 pairs of legs, 2 antennae, and usually one or two pairs of wings. Includes flies, mosquitoes, beetles, butterflies, bees, crickets, and dragonflies.

children.label: butterflies and moths
children.definition: Insects of the order Lepidoptera that have four wings with overlapping, often highly colored scales. They undergo four life cycle stages: eggs, caterpillar larvae, pupae, and the winged adults.

children.label: trilobites
children.definition: Extinct marine arthropods of the class Trilobita with segmented bodies and jointed appendages found as Paleozoic fossils in many parts of the world.

children.label: bryozoans and brachiopods
children.definition: Aquatic invertebrates, usually marine, belonging to the phyla Bryozoa and Brachiopoda.  Brachiopods, or clam shells, are solitary living invertebrates characterized by two shells and a lophophore, which is a complex food gathering organ.  Bryozoans are colonial and include moss coral and moss polyps.

children.label: coelenterates
children.definition: Freshwater and marine invertebrates, such as corals, jellyfish, and sea anemones, belonging to the phylum Coelenterata and living as sedentary polyps or free swimming medusae.

children.label: conodonts
children.definition: Microscopic teeth of primitive, boneless, eel-like animals, similar to modern hagfish, that lived in many of the world's oceans from the Cambrian through Triassic Periods of geologic time (550 to 210 million years ago).

children.label: echinoderms
children.definition: Marine invertebrates of the phylum Echinodermata with a radial body and a calcareous exoskeleton. Includes starfishes, brittle stars, sea lilies, sea urchins, and sea cucumbers.

children.label: mollusks
children.definition: Invertebrates belonging to the phylum Mollusca with soft, nonsegmented bodies, often covered by a hard shell.  Includes snails, clams, oysters, whelks, mussels, slugs, octopuses, and squids.

children.label: sponges
children.definition: Aquatic invertebrates belonging to the phylum Porifera having internal skeletons of silica or collagen, porous body around a cavity or cavities, and usually living in stationary communities.

children.label: worms
children.definition: Invertebrate animals of the phyla Annelida, Nematoda, Memertea, or Plathyhelminthes, that have long thin rounded or flat bodies without obvious appendages.

children.label: flatworms
children.definition: Soft flat worms of the phylum Platyhelminthes, which are often parasitic. Includes tapeworms and flukes.

children.label: roundworms
children.definition: Worms of the phylum Nematoda, often parasitic, such as hookworms and pinworms, having soft cylindrical bodies without segments.

children.label: segmented worms
children.definition: Worms belonging to the phylum Annelida, with soft bodies divided into segments and distinct heads. Includes leeches, earthworms, and marine worms.

children.label: tunicates
children.definition: Marine organisms of the subphylum tunicata of the phylum chordata.

children.label: vertebrates
children.definition: Animals possessing a vertebral column or backbone including birds, fishes, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals.

children.label: amphibians
children.definition: Vertebrates of the class Amphibia including frogs and toads (Anura), salamanders (Urodela), caecilians (Apoda) and extinct forms which are cold-blooded and have life stages in water as eggs and larval forms (tadpoles)until they metamorphose as adults.

children.label: birds
children.definition: Land vertebrates belonging to the class Aves with warm blood, feathers, wings, and reproduction characterized by egg laying.

children.label: fish
children.definition: Cold-blooded aquatic vertebrates with fins for swimming, gills for breathing, and usually scales.

children.label: mammals
children.definition: Vertebrate animals, generally large, with skin covered by hair and large brain cavities.  Females have mammary glands for feeding the young, who are usually born quite mature.

children.label: bears
children.definition: Large wild mammals of the family Ursidae.  Includes black and brown (grizzly) bears and polar bears.

children.label: bats
children.definition: Small flying mammals of the order Chiroptera.

children.label: reptiles
children.definition: Cold-blooded vertebrates of the class Reptilia.  Characterized by skin covered with scales or horny plates and reproduced by eggs. Includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, alligators, turtles, and extinct species such as dinosaurs.

children.label: dinosaurs
children.definition: Extinct reptiles, often gigantic, chiefly terrestrial, carnivorous or herbivorous, that lived during the Mesozoic era.

children.label: archaea
children.definition: Microscopic organisms of the domain Archaea living on a diet of hydrogen and carbon dioxide, once thought to be bacteria, and often inhabiting extreme environments, such as thermal vents and hot springs, extremely alkaline and acidic waters, hypersaline water, and anoxic habitats.

children.label: bacteria
children.definition: Single celled microorganisms, beneficial or pathogenic, without a nuclear membrane.

children.label: fungi
children.definition: Immobile organisms of the kingdom Fungi that lack chlorophyll and that obtain nutrients from other dead or living organisms. Fungi reproduce by spores and include yeasts, molds, smuts, and mushrooms.

children.label: lichens
children.definition: Plants that are composed of a fungus and an alga growing together symbiotically and often found growing on rocks or tree trunks.

children.label: plants (organisms)
children.definition: Organisms which belong to the plant kingdom. Commonly multicellular, they produce food through photosynthesis.

children.label: nonvascular plants
children.definition: Simple plants which lack conducting tissues known as vascular bundles, a group of specialized cells made up of xylem and phloem.

children.label: liverworts and hornworts
children.definition: Simple green land plants of the phyla Bryophyta with leaves and a stem and always without roots.

children.label: mosses
children.definition: Simple green land plants, member of the phyla Bryophyta, along with liverworts and hornworts.  They have leaves and a stem, but always lack roots.

children.label: vascular plants
children.definition: Plants which have a specialized conductive system. Includes xylem and phloem: club mosses, ferns, cycads, gymnosperms, and angiosperms.

children.label: ferns and fern allies
children.definition: Spore-bearing, vascular plants having leaves known as fronds.

children.label: flowering plants
children.definition: Plants known as angiosperms which periodically produce flowers which have various parts including sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels.

children.label: gymnosperms
children.definition: Seed-bearing woody vascular plants, such as the conifers (pine, spruce, fir, etc.), whose seeds are not enclosed in an ovary or fruit, but are exposed.

children.label: protists
children.definition: Unicellular eukaryotes (organisms possessing nucleated cells) with affinities to both plants and animals. Classed in the Protista or Potoctista kingdom, they include protozoans, foraminifera, radiolarians, fungi and some algae.

children.label: viruses
children.definition: Very small particles visible only with an electronic microscope. Considered to be complex molecules and not living organisms, these are often causes of disease in plants, animals, and bacteria.

children.label: planetary bodies
children.definition: Large celestial masses of rock, metal, or gas orbiting around a star.  Use for extraterrestrial bodies.

children.label: meteorites
children.definition: Masses of rock or metal from space that reach the earth's surface without burning up.  Use for 'meteors' or 'meteoroids' as well as 'meteorites'. USGS is more likely to have information about 'meteorites' since these are objects found on the earth.

children.label: population and community ecology
children.definition: Interactions of a single species (population) or an association of different species (community) occupying a particular region, including their biotic and abiotic environments.

children.label: animal behavior
children.definition: The way animals act or react to conditions in the environment and to other organisms, including life patterns such as migration, hibernation, and nocturnal living.

children.label: biodiversity
children.definition: The variety in form, genetics, and ecological roles of organisms within a specific geographic area.

children.label: ecosystem diversity
children.definition: Measure of the variety of biological communities and habitats important for ecological stability.

children.label: environmental DNA
children.definition: Nuclear or mitochondrial DNA released into the environment as bodily secretions, hair, or similar materials other than whole individuals.  Used to detect organisms that are not observed directly.

children.label: genetic diversity
children.definition: Measure of the variety of genes within a population pool in a given area.

children.label: genotype
children.definition: Genetic characteristics of an individual organism.

children.label: species diversity
children.definition: An ecological concept incorporating both the number of species in a particular sampling area and the evenness with which individuals are distributed among the various species.

children.label: biogeography
children.definition: The study of the geographic distributions of plants and animals.

children.label: community ecology
children.definition: Study of the relationships of species that interact in a common area.

children.label: ecosystems
children.definition: The interacting populations of plants, animals, and  microorganisms occupying a certain area, and their relationship to the environment.

children.label: aquatic ecosystems
children.definition: Communities of interdependent organisms living primarily in or on water.

children.label: benthic ecosystems
children.definition: Biologic communities and habitats at the bottom of lakes, streams, or oceans.

children.label: estuarine ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats within sea inlets or the zones where rivers meet the seas which are subject to tidal effects and the mixture of fresh and saltwater.

children.label: freshwater ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats that exist in lakes, rivers, ponds, and other bodies of water that are not salty.

children.label: marine ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities composed of plants and animals living primarily in or on seawater.

children.label: reef ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities formed by the skeletons of calcareous seawater organisms, usually corals.

children.label: terrestrial ecosystems
children.definition: Communities of living organisms in a specific geographical location which exist primarily on land and not in water.

children.label: coastal ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats within the narrow zones of land between the margin of oceans or seas and large landmasses.

children.label: desert ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats in arid areas with little precipitation, sparse, highly adapted vegetation, and extreme temperatures.

children.label: forest ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats in geographic areas with dense growths of trees and associated vegetation.

children.label: grassland ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats with ground cover of grasses and other herbaceous plants, but few trees.  Examples include prairies, meadows, and savannas.

children.label: shrubland ecosystems
children.definition: Biological land communities and habitats with sparse, low-growing vegetation.

children.label: tundra ecosystems
children.definition: Biological communities and habitats located in the treeless plains of Arctic regions where the subsoil is permanently frozen.

children.label: island ecosystems
children.definition: Communities of living organisms on islands.

children.label: wetland ecosystems
children.definition: Ecosystems whose soil is saturated for long periods seasonally or continuously, including marshes, swamps, and ephemeral ponds.  More detailed terms for wetlands can be selected from the FGDC Wetland Classification <http://fgdc.gov/standards/status/sub3_4.html>.

children.label: habitats
children.definition: Parts of the physical environment where plants and animals live. Use in combination with terms from organisms and organism groupings (non-taxonomic) to indicate the topic of a species or group of species habitat.

children.label: population dynamics
children.definition: Changes in the size, composition, or structure of aggregates of single or multiple species in a specific area over time.

children.label: symbiosis
children.definition: An intimate, prolonged association between two or more organisms of different species that may or may not benefit each member.

children.label: phenology
children.definition: Study of the response of organisms to seasonal or interannual changes in the environment.

children.label: scientific careers
children.definition: Professions in which people carry out or support scientific research or monitoring.

children.label: water properties
children.definition: Measurable physical and chemical characteristics of water from different sources.

children.label: nutrient content (water)
children.definition: Contaminants in water that nourish organisms, especially plants. Includes nitrogen and phosphorus, either of which can lead to the harmful growth of algae and other plants when present to excess in a body of water.

children.label: oxygen content (water)
children.definition: Measurement of the concentration of oxygen dissolved in water, which is an important indicator of the condition of a water body.

children.label: salinity
children.definition: Measure of the concentration of salts dissolved in a solution.

children.label: suspended material (water)
children.definition: Sediment or organic material carried in suspension in the water column, in contrast to material that moves on or near the bottom. May be measured directly by sampling, or indirectly by acoustic or optical backscatter or transmission.

children.label: water hardness
children.definition: Indicator of the concentration of alkaline salts in water, mainly calcium and magnesium, as a measure of water quality.

children.label: water pH
children.definition: The negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration or activity of a water solution. Used for expressing both acidity (pH less than 7) and alkalinity (pH greater than 7), with 7 considered neutral.

children.label: water temperature
children.definition: The degrees of heat of water from a given source at a specific time.

children.label: dissolved gases
children.definition: Gases such as ammonia, oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide in solution measured in a water sample.

children.label: dissolved metals
children.definition: Metal elements in solution, of concern in studies of hazards such as mine drainage and of water resource usability.

children.label: dissolved organic compounds
children.definition: Organic compounds present in water, typically as anthropogenic contaminants including pharmaceuticals, pesticides, and herbicides.

children.label: sound velocity
children.definition: Estimates of the velocity of sound in water, indexed by depth at a specific location, usually calculated from other water properties.

children.label: water column reflectivity
children.definition: A measure of the strength of reflection from small particles suspended in water. It is usually measured by sending a pulse of sound or light through the water and measuring the sound or light that is returned. Water column reflectivity can be used to measure the concentration of suspended particles.

children.label: water quality
children.definition: The chemical, physical, and biological characteristics of water, usually in respect to its suitability for a particular purpose.

children.label: groundwater quality
children.definition: Fitness of subsurface water for use based on its composition and properties.

children.label: marine water quality
children.definition: Observed intrinsic characteristics of marine waters affecting their ability to support life or facilitate biological processes such as waste decomposition.

children.label: surface water quality
children.definition: Chemical, physical, and biological characteristics of water in lakes, rivers, or streams related to its fitness for use.

children.label: water supply and demand
children.definition: The quantities of water resources in an area that are easily available and the amount of water that is needed for all uses.

children.label: wastewater discharge
children.definition: Water that is returned or reused after release from a wastewater treatment plant.

children.label: water budget
children.definition: An accounting of the inflow, outflow, and storage changes of water in a hydrologic unit.

children.label: water use
children.definition: Water withdrawal for a specific purpose, such as domestic use, irrigation, or industrial processing.

children.label: domestic well water use
children.definition: Use of self-supplied water for household purposes, such as drinking, food preparation, bathing, washing clothes and dishes, flushing toilets, and watering lawns and gardens.

children.label: industrial water use
children.definition: Use of water for industrial purposes such as fabrication, processing, washing, and cooling, and including such industries as steel, chemical and allied products, paper and allied products, mining, and petroleum refining.

children.label: irrigation
children.definition: Artificial application of water on lands to assist in the growing of crops and pastures or to maintain vegetative growth in recreational lands such as parks and golf courses.

children.label: mining water use
children.definition: Water use for the extraction of naturally occurring mineral deposits by mining or quarrying.

children.label: power generation water use
children.definition: Use of water in the process of producing electric energy by transforming other forms of energy.

children.label: public supply water use
children.definition: Provision of water by local governments or private companies for residential, commercial, and light industrial use.

children.label: aquaculture water use
children.definition: Use of water to raise aquatic organisms, typically for food, restoration, conservation, or sport.

children.label: recreation
children.definition: Pursuit of leisure-time activities, typically out of doors.

children.label: field monitoring stations
children.definition: Locations where USGS scientists or their collaborators make measurements of natural phenomena.

children.label: elements
children.definition: Chemical elements and element groups

children.label: chemical element groups
children.definition: Groups shown at <http://periodic.lanl.gov/>

children.label: rare earth elements
children.definition: A group of elements including the lanthanoids, or lanthanides, of interest because they are used in modern technological industries.  Yttrium and scandium are often included in this group.

children.label: platinum-group elements
children.definition: A group of chemically similar metal elements that tend to occur in the same types of mineral deposits.
